Private sampling: a noiseless approach for generating differentially private synthetic data

March Boedihardjo Department of Mathematics, University of California Irvine marchb@uci.edu ,¬† Thomas Strohmer Center of Data Science and Artificial Intelligence Research University of California, Davis
and Department of Mathematics, University of California Davis strohmer@math.ucdavis.edu ¬†and¬† Roman Vershynin Department of Mathematics, University of California Irvine rvershyn@uci.edu
Abstract.

In a world where artificial intelligence and data science become omnipresent, data sharing is increasingly locking horns with data-privacy concerns. Differential privacy has emerged as a rigorous framework for protecting individual privacy in a statistical database, while releasing useful statistical information about the database. The standard way to implement differential privacy is to inject a sufficient amount of noise into the data. However, in addition to other limitations of differential privacy, this process of adding noise will affect data accuracy and utility. Another approach to enable privacy in data sharing is based on the concept of synthetic data. The goal of synthetic data is to create an as-realistic-as-possible dataset, one that not only maintains the nuances of the original data, but does so without risk of exposing sensitive information. The combination of differential privacy with synthetic data has been suggested as a best-of-both-worlds solutions. In this work, we propose the first noisefree method to construct differentially private synthetic data; we do this through a mechanism called ‚Äúprivate sampling‚Äù. Using the Boolean cube as benchmark data model, we derive explicit bounds on accuracy and privacy of the constructed synthetic data. The key mathematical tools are hypercontractivity, duality, and empirical processes. A core ingredient of our private sampling mechanism is a rigorous ‚Äúmarginal correction‚Äù method, which has the remarkable property that importance reweighting can be utilized to exactly match the marginals of the sample to the marginals of the population.

1. Introduction

In a world where artificial intelligence and data science are penetrating more and more aspects of our life, data sharing is increasingly locking horns with data-privacy concerns. This conflict is playing out around the globe, as private and public organizations are trying to find ways to share data without compromising sensitive personal information.

There exist various attempts to protect sensitive information in data. Historically the way to share private information without betraying privacy was through anonymization¬†[45], i.e., by stripping away enough identifying information from a dataset, so that the so-modified data could be shared freely. Anonymization, however, proved to be a fragile means to protect data privacy. In actuality, identifying individuals using seemingly non-unique identifiers is far easier than proponents of data anonymization expected. For instance, Netflix and AOL customers were all accurately identified from purportedly anonymized data. De-identification requires precise definitions of ‚Äúunique identifiers‚Äù. Furthermore, de-identification suffers from an aging problem: it is already quite difficult enough to determine exactly what data identifies information that needs to be protected (say, the identity of individuals), but it is even more difficult to accurately predict what potential auxiliary information could be available in the future. This leads to an arms race between de-identification and re-identification.

The well-documented failures of anonymization have prompted aggressive research on data sanitization, ranging from kùëòk-anonymity¬†[38, 5] to today‚Äôs highly acclaimed differential privacy¬†[21]. The concept of k-anonymity was introduced to address the risk of re-identification of anonymized data through linkage to other datasets. The idea behind kùëòk-anonymity is to maintain privacy by guaranteeing that for every record in a database there are kùëòk of indistinguishable copies.

Differential privacy is a framework to quantify the extent to which individual privacy in a statistical database is preserved while releasing useful statistical information about the database¬†[21]. Differential privacy is a popular and robust method that comes with a rigorous mathematical framework and provable guarantees. Differential privacy can protect aggregate information, but not sensitive information in general. Also, if enough identical queries are asked, the protection provided by differential privacy is diluted. Additionally, if the query being asked requires high specificity, then it is more difficult to uphold differential privacy. In any case, in all the aforementioned methods the basic tradeoff between utility and privacy represents a serious limitation.

Synthetic data provide a promising concept to solve this conundrum¬†[7]. The goal of synthetic data is to create an as-realistic-as-possible dataset, one that not only maintains the nuances of the original data, but does so without risk of exposing sensitive information. Synthetic datasets are generated from existing datasets and maintain the statistical properties of the original dataset. Since (ideally) synthetic data contain no protected information, the datasets can be shared freely among investigators in academia or industry, without security and privacy concerns.

It has been frequently recommended that synthetic data may be combined with differential privacy to achieve a best-of-both-worlds scenario¬†[23, 7, 27, 29, 10]. As observed in¬†[7], ‚ÄúThe most ideal data to use in any analysis will always be original data. But when that option is not available, synthetic data plus differential privacy offers a great compromise.‚Äù Synthetic data are not only a succinct way of representing the answers to large numbers of queries, but they also permit one to carry out other data analysis tasks, such as visualization or regression.

The standard way to achieve differential privacy is to add noise, either to the data queries, the data themselves, or in case of synthetic data during the data generation process, for a small sample of work see e.g.¬†[21, 23, 24, 3, 29, 16]. Unfortunately, noise will negatively affect utility and can inject systematic errors‚Äîhence bias‚Äîinto the data¬†[36, 47, 22]. To illustrate these issues, assume the dataset under consideration consists of images, each depicting the face of a person. We can attempt to generate a differentially private synthetic dataset by adding a sufficient amount of noise to each image (e.g., by adding random noise¬†[32] or by distorting or blurring the images¬†[37, 44]), such that the persons in the images can no longer be identified. Ignoring for the moment the possibility of re-identifying a person by applying denoising or deblurring techniques to the distorted images, it is clear that utility of this dataset can decrease significantly during this process of adding noise, perhaps to the point that many of the nuances one might be interested in are no longer present.

To illuminate the effect of introducing systematic error when adding noise to ensure differential privacy, we just need to look at the issues reported with differentially private US Census 2020 demonstration data, which have resulted in diminished quality of statistics for small populations such as tribal nations¬†[42, 36, 22].

These considerations raise a fundamental question:

Can we generate differentially private synthetic data without adding noise?

In this paper, we give a positive and constructive answer. Using the Boolean cube as our data model, we will develop a noiseless method to generate synthetic data, which approximately preserve low-dimensional marginals of the original dataset. Our method is based on a private sampling framework and comes with explicit bounds on privacy and accuracy. The key mathematical tools are hypercontractivity, duality, and empirical processes. A core ingredient of our private sampling framework is a rigorous ‚Äúmarginal correction‚Äù method, which has the remarkable property that importance reweighting can be utilized to exactly match the marginals of the sample to the marginals of the population.

There exist other methods to generate differentially private synthetic data without adding noise, such as those based on generative adversarial networks¬†[30, 1, 12, 46, 17]. However, these methods are just empirical and do not come with any rigorous bounds regarding accuracy or privacy. Those deep learning based methods that do come with privacy guarantees‚Äîbut still without any accuracy guarantees‚Äîrequire injecting noise into the synthetic data generation process¬†[43, 26, 6].

2. Synthetic data and differential privacy

Differential privacy has emerged as the de facto standard for guaranteeing privacy in data sharing. Recall the definition of differential privacy:

Definition 2.1 (Differential Privacy¬†[21]).

A randomized mechanism ‚Ñ≥:ùíÆN‚Üí‚Ñõ:‚Ñ≥superscriptùíÆùëÅ‚Üí‚Ñõ{\mathcal{M}}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}{\mathcal{S}}^{N}\to{\mathcal{R}} satisfies ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon-differential privacy if for any two adjacent datasets X1,X2‚ààùíÆNsubscriptùëã1subscriptùëã2superscriptùíÆùëÅX_{1},X_{2}\in{\mathcal{S}}^{N} differing by one element, and any output subset ùí™‚àà‚Ñõùí™‚Ñõ{\mathcal{O}}\in{\mathcal{R}} it holds that

‚Ñô‚Äã[‚Ñ≥‚Äã(X1)‚ààùí™]‚â§eŒµ‚ãÖ‚Ñô‚Äã[‚Ñ≥‚Äã(X2)‚ààùí™].‚Ñôdelimited-[]‚Ñ≥subscriptùëã1ùí™‚ãÖsuperscriptùëíùúÄ‚Ñôdelimited-[]‚Ñ≥subscriptùëã2ùí™{\mathbb{P}}[{\mathcal{M}}(X_{1})\in{\mathcal{O}}]\leq e^{\varepsilon}\cdot{\mathbb{P}}[{\mathcal{M}}(X_{2})\in{\mathcal{O}}].

Numerous techniques have been proposed for generating privacy-preserving synthetic data (e.g.¬†[2, 13, 1, 15, 31]), but without providing formal privacy guarantees. Almost all existing mechanisms to implement differential privacy inject some sort of noise into the data or the data queries, see e.g.¬†the Laplacian mechanism¬†[19]. This is also the case for differentially private synthetic data, see for instance¬†[28, 4].

Obviously, we want our synthetic data to be similar to the original data. To that end we need some metrics to measure similarity. A common and natural choice is to try to (approximately) preserve low-dimensional marginals¬†[4, 39]. A marginal of the data XùëãX is the fraction of the elements xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i} with specified values of specified parameters. On the one hand, marginals are important in their own right as a tool of statistical analysis. On the other hand, if the synthetic data preserve e.g.¬†two-dimensional marginals (i.e., covariance matrices) with sufficient accuracy, the synthetic dataset is expected to inherit other significant properties from the original dataset, such as similar behavior with respect to clustering, classification or regression111So far this expectation has only been verified empirically in various papers, while a rigorous mathematical verification is an important open problem..

However, we are immediately met with a remarkable no-go theorem due to Ullman and Vadhan¬†[40]. They proved the surprising result that (under standard cryptographic assumptions) there is no polynomial-time differentially private algorithm that takes a dataset X‚àà({0,1}p)nùëãsuperscriptsuperscript01ùëùùëõX\in(\{0,1\}^{p})^{n} and outputs a synthetic dataset Y‚àà({0,1}p)kùëåsuperscriptsuperscript01ùëùùëòY\in(\{0,1\}^{p})^{k} such that all two-dimensional marginals of YùëåY are approximately equal to those of XùëãX.

There is an extensive literature on privately releasing answers to linear queries, but without producing synthetic data, see e.g.¬†[25, 33, 20] for a small sample. Another line of important work deals with with privacy-preserving data analysis in a statistical framework¬†[18, 14]; but they also are not concerned with synthetic data. The papers¬†[4, 24, 23, 9] propose a range of interesting methods for producing approximately accurate private synthetic data. However, the associated algorithms have running time that is at least exponential in pùëùp.

Luckily, already a slightly relaxed formulation of the worst-case no-go result in¬†[40] already leads to positive results. For example, if we relax ‚Äúall marginals‚Äù to ‚Äúmost marginals‚Äù, it is shown in¬†[10] that there exists a polynomial-time differentially private algorithm generating synthetic data Y‚àà({0,1}p)kùëåsuperscriptsuperscript01ùëùùëòY\in(\{0,1\}^{p})^{k} such that the error between the marginals of YùëåY and XùëãX is small. Remarkably, the result does not only hold for two-dimensional marginals, but for marginals of all dimensions. If we relax ‚Äúworst data‚Äù to ‚Äútypical data‚Äù, generating accurate differentially private synthetic Boolean (or other domain constrained) data becomes tractable¬†[11].

Yet, in all the aforementioned papers differential privacy is achieved by adding noise during the data generation process. In this paper we propose an alternative, noise-free, mechanism called private sampling.

3. Main result

We model the true data X=(x1,‚Ä¶,xn)ùëãsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõX=(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}) as a sequence of nùëõn points from the Boolean cube {0,1}psuperscript01ùëù\{0,1\}^{p}, which is a standard benchmark data model¬†[4, 40, 23, 35, 29, 8]. For example, XùëãX might represent the health records of nùëõn patients, where each health record consists of pùëùp parameters. These parameters are 0/1010/1 numbers that represent the answers to the standard health history questionnaire, such as ‚Äúdoes the patient smoke?‚Äù, ‚Äúdoes the patient have diabetes?‚Äù. We can also represent categorical data (gender, occupation, etc.) or numerical data (by splitting them into intervals) on the Boolean cube via binary or one-hot encoding.

We would like to manufacture a synthetic dataset Y=(y1,‚Ä¶,yk)ùëåsubscriptùë¶1‚Ä¶subscriptùë¶ùëòY=(y_{1},\ldots,y_{k}), another sequence of kùëòk elements of the cube. Our two desiderata are privacy and accuracy. Specifically, we would like the synthetic data to be differentially private, and all low-dimensional marginals of YùëåY to exactly or approximately match those of XùëãX.

We recall that on the Boolean cube, a marginal of a function f:{‚àí1,1}p‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëìsuperscript11ùëù‚Üí‚Ñùf\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\{-1,1\}^{p}\to\mathbb{R} is defined as a sum of values of fùëìf on the points of the cube that have specified values of specified parameters. For example, a two-dimensional marginal of fùëìf is ‚àëx‚àà{‚àí1,1}pf‚Äã(x)‚Äã1{x‚Äã(1)=x‚Äã(2)=1}‚Äã(x)subscriptùë•superscript11ùëùùëìùë•subscript1ùë•1ùë•21ùë•\sum_{x\in\{-1,1\}^{p}}f(x){\textbf{1}}_{\{x(1)=x(2)=1\}}(x). If fùëìf is a density, a marginal can be interpreted as the probability that a random point ZùëçZ drawn from the cube according to fùëìf has specified values of specified parameters; in the example below it is ‚Ñô‚Äã{Z‚Äã(1)=Z‚Äã(2)=1‚Äã}‚Ñôùëç1ùëç21\mathbb{P}\left\{Z(1)=Z(2)=1\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}. Marginals of the data X=(x1,‚Ä¶,xn)ùëãsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõX=(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}) can be interpreted as marginals of the uniform density fn=1n‚Äã‚àëi=1n1xisubscriptùëìùëõ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscript1subscriptùë•ùëñf_{n}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\textbf{1}}_{x_{i}} on XùëãX. An example of a two-dimensional marginal is the fraction of elements xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i} whose first and second parameters equal 111, i.e. 1n‚Äã‚àëi=1n1{xi‚Äã(1)=xi‚Äã(2)=1}1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscript1subscriptùë•ùëñ1subscriptùë•ùëñ21\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\textbf{1}}_{\{x_{i}(1)=x_{i}(2)=1\}}. This could represent for example the number of patients who smoke and have diabetes.

Here we explore a new noiseless approach: take a new sample S=(s1,‚Ä¶,sm)ùëÜsubscriptùë†1‚Ä¶subscriptùë†ùëöS=(s_{1},\ldots,s_{m}) uniformly from the cube, reweight SùëÜS to make the marginals match those of the true data XùëãX, and resample from the weighted sample SùëÜS.

But is this even possible? Let us assume the dataset X=(x1,‚Ä¶,xn)ùëãsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõX=(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}) is drawn from the cube independently and according to some unknown density. Draw a new sample S=(s1,‚Ä¶,sm)ùëÜsubscriptùë†1‚Ä¶subscriptùë†ùëöS=(s_{1},\ldots,s_{m}) according to some known density, for example uniformly from the cube222Since the cardinality of SùëÜS will be chosen to be smaller than that of the dataset XùëãX, we call SùëÜS also the reduced space. . Can we reweight SùëÜS so that the reweighted sample has approximately the same marginals as XùëãX? Note that there are precisely (p‚â§d)binomialùëùabsentùëë\binom{p}{\leq d} marginals of degree at most dùëëd, where (p‚â§d):=(p0)+(p1)+‚ãØ+(pd)\binom{p}{\leq d}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}=\binom{p}{0}+\binom{p}{1}+\cdots+\binom{p}{d}. Surprisingly, we can even match all marginals exactly.

Let us state it this result informally; a rigorous, non-asymptotic and more general statement is given in Theorem¬†8.1.

Theorem 3.1 (Matching marginals).

Consider two regularly varying densities333A density fùëìf is regularly varying if supf‚Äã(x)/f‚Äã(y)=O‚Äã(1)supremumùëìùë•ùëìùë¶ùëÇ1\sup f(x)/f(y)=O(1) where the supremum is over all points xùë•x and yùë¶y in the cube. Our results are more general; as we will see shortly, the regularity assumption can be relaxed. on the cube {0,1}psuperscript01ùëù\{0,1\}^{p}, and draw two independent samples XùëãX and SùëÜS from the cube according to these two distributions. If min‚Å°(|X|,|S|)‚â´e2‚Äãd‚Äã(p‚â§d)much-greater-thanùëãùëÜsuperscriptùëí2ùëëbinomialùëùabsentùëë\min(\mathinner{\!\left\lvert X\right\rvert},\mathinner{\!\left\lvert S\right\rvert})\gg e^{2d}\binom{p}{\leq d}, then with probability 1‚àío‚Äã(1)1ùëú11-o(1) there exists a density on SùëÜS that has exactly the same marginals up to dimension dùëëd as the uniform distribution on XùëãX.

Remark 3.2.

To match all (p‚â§d)binomialùëùabsentùëë\binom{p}{\leq d} marginals of dimension at most dùëëd, it makes sense to have at least as many data points. This explains the requirement on nùëõn in the theorem heuristically (but not rigorously). The prefactor e2‚Äãdsuperscriptùëí2ùëëe^{2d} is negligible compared to (p‚â§d)binomialùëùabsentùëë\binom{p}{\leq d} if d‚â™pmuch-less-thanùëëùëùd\ll p.

As a ‚Äúnon-example‚Äù for Theorem¬†3.1, consider a probability measure supported on the set of patients whose first parameter equals 00, and a different probability measure supported on the set of patients whose first parameter equals 111. Then even a one-dimensional marginal ‚Äì the distribution of the first parameter ‚Äì will be different for XùëãX and YùëåY, no matter how YùëåY is reweighted. This example shows that some form of regularity assumption will be required in the theorem.

The density h‚àósuperscript‚Ñéh^{*} on SùëÜS that is guaranteed by Theorem¬†3.1 can be computed efficiently. Indeed, this task can be set up as a linear program with |S|ùëÜ\mathinner{\!\left\lvert S\right\rvert} variables (the values of the density on SùëÜS), (p‚â§d)binomialùëùabsentùëë\binom{p}{\leq d} linear equations (to match the marginals to those of XùëãX), and |S|ùëÜ\mathinner{\!\left\lvert S\right\rvert} linear inequalities (to ensure the density is nonnegative on SùëÜS).

Once this density h‚àósuperscript‚Ñéh^{*} is computed, we can generate synthetic data Y=(y1,‚Ä¶,yk)ùëåsubscriptùë¶1‚Ä¶subscriptùë¶ùëòY=(y_{1},\ldots,y_{k}) by drawing independent points from SùëÜS according to the density h‚àósuperscript‚Ñéh^{*}.

3.1. Private sampling

Is such synthetic data YùëåY private? Here is a general tool that basically says: yes, YùëåY is private as long as the density h‚àósuperscript‚Ñéh^{*} has bounded sensitivity.

Lemma 3.3 (Private sampling).

Let Œ©Œ©\Omega be a finite set. Let fùëìf be a mapping that takes a dataset XùëãX as input and returns a probability mass function f‚Äã(X)ùëìùëãf(X) on Œ©Œ©\Omega. Suppose Œµ>0ùúÄ0\varepsilon>0 and k‚àà‚Ñïùëò‚Ñïk\in\mathbb{N} are chosen so that

‚à•f‚Äã(X1)/f‚Äã(X2)‚à•‚àû‚â§exp‚Å°(Œµ/k)subscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëìsubscriptùëã1ùëìsubscriptùëã2ùúÄùëò\mathinner{\!\left\lVert f(X_{1})/f(X_{2})\right\rVert}_{\infty}\leq\exp(\varepsilon/k)

for all datasets X1subscriptùëã1X_{1} and X2subscriptùëã2X_{2} that differ on a single element. Then the algorithm that takes XùëãX as input and returns a sample of kùëòk points drawn from Œ©Œ©\Omega independently and according to the distribution f‚Äã(X)ùëìùëãf(X) is ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon-differentially private.

Proof.

The probability that a given kùëòk-tuple of points œâ1,‚Ä¶,œâk‚ààŒ©subscriptùúî1‚Ä¶subscriptùúîùëòŒ©\omega_{1},\ldots,\omega_{k}\in\Omega is drawn when sampled from distribution f‚Äã(X1)ùëìsubscriptùëã1f(X_{1}) equals ‚àèi=1kf‚Äã(X1)‚Äã(œâi)superscriptsubscriptproductùëñ1ùëòùëìsubscriptùëã1subscriptùúîùëñ\prod_{i=1}^{k}f(X_{1})(\omega_{i}). Similarly, the probability that this same tuple is drawn when sampled from distribution f‚Äã(X2)ùëìsubscriptùëã2f(X_{2}) equals ‚àèi=1kf‚Äã(X2)‚Äã(œâi)superscriptsubscriptproductùëñ1ùëòùëìsubscriptùëã2subscriptùúîùëñ\prod_{i=1}^{k}f(X_{2})(\omega_{i}). This means that the sampling mechanism is ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon-differentially private. ‚àé

3.2. Difficulties and their resolution

Unfortunately, the density h‚àósuperscript‚Ñéh^{*} guaranteed by Theorem¬†3.1 is too sensitive. Indeed, the sensitivity bound in Lemma¬†3.3 needs to be proved for arbitrary input data, while Theorem¬†3.1 only works with high probability. For some input data XùëãX, a suitable density exists, and for another input data ZùëçZ, no suitable density exists. Moving from XùëãX toward ZùëçZ by changing one data point at a time, we can find a pair of datasets X1subscriptùëã1X_{1} and X2subscriptùëã2X_{2} that differ in a single data point so that the algorithm succeeds to find a density for X1subscriptùëã1X_{1} and fails for X2subscriptùëã2X_{2}. This means that the algorithm is non-private.

The other issue is that there can be (and usually are) many suitable densities h‚àósuperscript‚Ñéh^{*}. Which one to chose? How to devise a selection rule that upholds privacy?

In other words, we need to work around the possible non-existence and non-uniqueness of the solution. We resolve both issues here. To ensure existence, we employ shrinking: we move the solution space (the set of all functions on SùëÜS, possibly negative-valued, that have the same marginals as XùëãX) toward the uniform density on SùëÜS until the resulting set contains a nonnegative function (thus a density). For the selection rule, we choose the closest solution to the uniform density on SùëÜS in the L2superscriptùêø2L^{2} metric.

Furthermore, while SùëÜS is chosen randomly, we do need SùëÜS to be well-conditioned in a sense that will be discussed in detail in Section¬†9. At this point suffice it to say that (i)¬†the well-conditionedness of SùëÜS can be expressed in terms of a bound on the smallest singular value œÉmin‚Äã(M)subscriptùúéùëÄ\sigma_{\min}(M) of the m√ó(p‚â§d)ùëöbinomialùëùabsentùëëm\times\binom{p}{\leq d} matrix MùëÄM with entries w‚Äã(s)ùë§ùë†w(s), where s‚ààSùë†ùëÜs\in S and wùë§w is a Walsh function444See Section¬†4 for basic definitions related to Fourier analysis of the Boolean cube. of degree at most dùëëd; (ii)¬†the well-conditionedness of MùëÄM can be easily achieved and easily verified.

This leads us to the algorithm outlined in the next subsection.

3.3. Algorithm

We provide a high-level description of our proposed method in Algorithm¬†1.

The well-conditionedness of SùëÜS in Algorithm¬†1 defined via the condition œÉmin‚Äã(M)>m/2‚ÄãedsubscriptùúéùëÄùëö2superscriptùëíùëë\sigma_{\min}(M)>\sqrt{m}/2e^{d} essentially says that the subsampled Walsh basis is almost orthogonal. The scaling mùëö\sqrt{m} is natural: the entries of MùëÄM all have absolute value 111, hence the columns of MùëÄM have Euclidean norm mùëö\sqrt{m}. If we had œÉmin‚Äã(M)=msubscriptùúéùëÄùëö\sigma_{\min}(M)=\sqrt{m}, this would imply that the columns of MùëÄM (the subsampled Walsh functions) are mutually orthogonal. We require a relaxed (by a factor 2‚Äãed2superscriptùëíùëë2e^{d}) version of this orthogonality.

What if SùëÜS fails the desired condition? We can simply resample SùëÜS until it is well conditioned. But this is only a useful strategy if the chances of success are sufficiently high. Under some mild conditions (see Section¬†9) success happens with probability >1/2absent12>1/2, hence the expected number or trials until success is ‚â§2absent2\leq 2. This way Algorithm¬†1 succeeds deterministically, but its running time becomes random (albeit with the rather modest expected overhead time ‚â§2absent2\leq 2).


Definition 3.4.

We say that the synthetic dataset YùëåY is Œ¥ùõø\delta-accurate if each of its marginals up to degree (or dimension) dùëëd is within Œ¥ùõø\delta from the corresponding marginal of the true dataset XùëãX.

The following theorem guarantees the accuracy and privacy of the algorithm. We state it informally here, and more accurately in Theorems¬†12.2 and 12.4.

Theorem 3.5 (Privacy and accuracy).

Let the size of the reduced space SùëÜS satisfy m‚âçe2‚Äãd‚Äã(p‚â§d)asymptotically-equalsùëösuperscriptùëí2ùëëbinomialùëùabsentùëëm\asymp e^{2d}\binom{p}{\leq d}.

  1. (a)

    Algorithm¬†1 succeeds (i.e. does not return ‚ÄúFailure‚Äù) with high probability.

  2. (b)

    If the size of the synthetic data satisfies k‚â™n/mmuch-less-thanùëòùëõùëök\ll\sqrt{n}/m, then Algorithm¬†1 is o‚Äã(1)ùëú1o(1)-differentially private.

  3. (c)

    Suppose n‚â´e2‚Äãd‚Äã(p‚â§d)much-greater-thanùëõsuperscriptùëí2ùëëbinomialùëùabsentùëën\gg e^{2d}\binom{p}{\leq d}, k‚â´log‚Å°(p‚â§d)much-greater-thanùëòbinomialùëùabsentùëëk\gg\log\binom{p}{\leq d}, and the true data points XùëãX are sampled independently from some density that is upper bounded by Œî/2pŒîsuperscript2ùëù\Delta/2^{p}. Then, with high probability, the synthetic data generated via Algorithm¬†1 is o‚Äã(1)ùëú1o(1)-accurate up to dimension dùëëd.

For a more formal presentation of Algorithm¬†1, see Algorithm¬†2 below. A formal version of part (a) of Theorem¬†3.5 is shown in Proposition¬†9.3; part (b) is shown in Theorem¬†12.2 and Remark¬†12.3; part (c) is shown in Theorem¬†12.4. The mathematical techniques to prove these results revolve around Fourier analysis of Boolean functions and empirical processes, see Sections¬†4‚Äì7.

In case the true data XùëãX is sampled form a regular density, the algorithm will not apply any shrinkage, since in this case Theorem¬†3.1 guarantees the existence of a solution. (We make this rigorous in Remark¬†12.5.) In this case, the private synthetic data YùëåY will be sampled in an unbiased way from the density h‚àósuperscript‚Ñéh^{*} that has exactly the same marginals as the true data XùëãX.

3.4. Further remarks

There is a one-sample version of Theorem¬†3.1. Let us state it here informally; a more accurate statement is given in Theorem¬†8.2.

Theorem 3.6 (Marginal correction).

Consider a regularly varying density fùëìf on the cube {0,1}psuperscript01ùëù\{0,1\}^{p} and draw an independent sample SùëÜS from the cube according to this distribution. If |S|‚â´e2‚Äãd‚Äã(p‚â§d)much-greater-thanùëÜsuperscriptùëí2ùëëbinomialùëùabsentùëë\mathinner{\!\left\lvert S\right\rvert}\gg e^{2d}\binom{p}{\leq d}, then with probability 1‚àío‚Äã(1)1ùëú11-o(1) there exists a density h‚Ñéh on SùëÜS that has exactly the same marginals as fùëìf up to dimension dùëëd. Moreover, h‚Ñéh is within a 1+o‚Äã(1)1ùëú11+o(1) factor of the uniform density on SùëÜS.

The law of large numbers tells us that the sample SùëÜS must have approximately the same marginals as the density fùëìf from which SùëÜS was drawn. Theorem¬†3.6 tells us that we can make the marginals exactly the same by a slight reweighting of SùëÜS, i.e. by weights that are all 1+o‚Äã(1)1ùëú11+o(1).

4. Fourier analysis

The proof of Theorem¬†3.1 is based on hypercontractivity, duality, and empirical processes.

Let us start by recalling the basic Fourier analysis on the Boolean cube¬†[34]. It is more convenient to work on {‚àí1,1}psuperscript11ùëù\{-1,1\}^{p} than on {0,1}psuperscript01ùëù\{0,1\}^{p}; all results are easily translatable from one cube to the other.

The Walsh functions wJ:{‚àí1,1}p‚Üí{‚àí1,1}:subscriptùë§ùêΩsuperscript11ùëù‚Üí11w_{J}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\{-1,1\}^{p}\to\{-1,1\} are indexed by subsets J‚äÇ[p]ùêΩdelimited-[]ùëùJ\subset[p] and are defined as

with the convention w‚àÖ=1subscriptùë§1w_{\emptyset}=1.

The canonical inner product on the space of real-valued functions on {‚àí1,1}psuperscript11ùëù\{-1,1\}^{p} is defined as

‚ü®f,g‚ü©L2=12p‚Äã‚àëx‚àà{‚àí1,1}pf‚Äã(x)‚Äãg‚Äã(x).subscriptùëìùëîsuperscriptùêø21superscript2ùëùsubscriptùë•superscript11ùëùùëìùë•ùëîùë•\langle f,g\rangle_{L^{2}}=\frac{1}{2^{p}}\sum_{x\in\{-1,1\}^{p}}f(x)\,g(x).

This inner product defines the space L2=L2‚Äã({‚àí1,1}p)superscriptùêø2superscriptùêø2superscript11ùëùL^{2}=L^{2}(\{-1,1\}^{p}). More generally, for 1‚â§q<‚àû1ùëû1\leq q<\infty, the Lq=Lq‚Äã({‚àí1,1}p)superscriptùêøùëûsuperscriptùêøùëûsuperscript11ùëùL^{q}=L^{q}(\{-1,1\}^{p}) is the space of real-valued functions on the cube with the norm

Clearly, the function f‚â§dsuperscriptùëìabsentùëëf^{\leq d} is determined by the Fourier coefficients of fùëìf up to dimension dùëëd, and vice versa.

and it has dimension (p‚â§d)binomialùëùabsentùëë\binom{p}{\leq d}. The orthogonal complement to this subspace in L2superscriptùêø2L^{2} is the ‚Äúhigh-frequency‚Äù subspace

The following result is well known, see [34, Theorem¬†9.22]:

Theorem 4.1 (Hypercontractivity).

For any d‚â§pùëëùëùd\leq p and any function f:{‚àí1,1}p‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëìsuperscript11ùëù‚Üí‚Ñùf\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\{-1,1\}^{p}\to\mathbb{R} of degree at most dùëëd, we have

4.1. Connection to marginals

The low-degree Fourier coefficients of f:{‚àí1,1}p‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëìsuperscript11ùëù‚Üí‚Ñùf\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\{-1,1\}^{p}\to\mathbb{R} determine the low-dimensional marginals of fùëìf. To see this, consider the example of the two-dimensional marginal in which the first parameter is set to 111 and the second is set fo ‚àí11-1. 6. Enforcing a uniform bound and sparsity

We will now prove that for any function FùêπF on the Boolean cube, there is another function that simultaneously satisfies the three desiderata: (a) it has the same marginals (or Fourier coefficients) as FùêπF up to dimension dùëëd; (b) it is very sparse ‚Äì in fact, it is supported on a random set of a given cardinality; and (c) it is uniformly bounded. The following result guarantees the existence of such function F‚àíwùêπùë§F-w.

Proof of Theorem¬†6.1.

Let us dualize Lemma¬†6.2 with respect to the inner product on L2superscriptùêø2L^{2}. The identity operator is self-adjoint, and the adjoint operator has the same norm. So, with probability at least 1‚àíŒ≥1ùõæ1-\gamma, for every Œ¥>0ùõø0\delta>0 we have

The Hilbert space L2superscriptùêø2L^{2} is self-dual. The dual to the weighted space LŒ¥1subscriptsuperscriptùêø1ùõøL^{1}_{\delta} is the weighted space L1/Œ¥‚àûsubscriptsuperscriptùêø1ùõøL^{\infty}_{1/\delta} defined as

(6.1)

The dual of a subspace is a quotient space of the dual:

as claimed in the theorem. Together with the first bound in (6.2), this proves that

‚à•F‚àíw‚à•‚àû‚â§B‚Äã‚à•F‚à•L2.subscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùêπùë§ùêµsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùêπsuperscriptùêø2\mathinner{\!\left\lVert F-w\right\rVert}_{\infty}\leq B\mathinner{\!\left\lVert F\right\rVert}_{L^{2}}.

Thus, we showed every function F:{‚àí1,1}p‚Üí‚Ñù:ùêπsuperscript11ùëù‚Üí‚ÑùF\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\{-1,1\}^{p}\to\mathbb{R} satisfies

inf{‚à•F‚àíw‚à•‚àû:w‚ààW>d,F‚àíw‚äÇSŒºm}‚â§B‚à•F‚à•L2\inf\left\{\mathinner{\!\left\lVert F-w\right\rVert}_{\infty}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\;w\in W^{>d},\,F-w\subset S_{\mu_{m}}\right\}\leq B\mathinner{\!\left\lVert F\right\rVert}_{L^{2}}

Finally, note that the term ‚à•F‚à•L2subscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùêπsuperscriptùêø2\mathinner{\!\left\lVert F\right\rVert}_{L^{2}} on the right hand side can automatically be improved to ‚à•F‚â§d‚à•L2subscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptùêπabsentùëësuperscriptùêø2\mathinner{\!\bigl{\lVert}F^{\leq d}\bigr{\rVert}}_{L^{2}}. 7. Low-degree projections of empirical measures

Consider two probability measures ŒΩùúà\nu and Œºùúá\mu on {‚àí1,1}psuperscript11ùëù\{-1,1\}^{p}, and let fùëìf and gùëîg denote their densities (or probability mass functions):

f‚Äã(z)=ŒΩ‚Äã({z})andg‚Äã(z)=Œº‚Äã({z}),z‚àà{‚àí1,1}p.formulae-sequenceùëìùëßùúàùëßandformulae-sequenceùëîùëßùúáùëßùëßsuperscript11ùëùf(z)=\nu(\{z\})\quad\text{and}\quad g(z)=\mu(\{z\}),\quad z\in\{-1,1\}^{p}.

The densities of the empirical probability measures ŒΩnsubscriptùúàùëõ\nu_{n} and Œºmsubscriptùúáùëö\mu_{m} are

fn=1n‚Äã‚àëi=1n1xiandgm=1m‚Äã‚àëi=1m1yiformulae-sequencesubscriptùëìùëõ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscript1subscriptùë•ùëñandsubscriptùëîùëö1ùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëösubscript1subscriptùë¶ùëñf_{n}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\textbf{1}}_{x_{i}}\quad\text{and}\quad g_{m}=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}{\textbf{1}}_{y_{i}} (7.1)

where x1,‚Ä¶,xnsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõx_{1},\ldots,x_{n} and y1,‚Ä¶,ymsubscriptùë¶1‚Ä¶subscriptùë¶ùëöy_{1},\ldots,y_{m} are i.i.d.¬†points drawn from the cube according to the densities fùëìf and gùëîg, respectively. The functions fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n} and gmsubscriptùëîùëög_{m} provide unbiased estimators of fùëìf and gùëîg:

ùîº‚Å°fn=f,ùîº‚Å°gm=g.formulae-sequenceùîºsubscriptùëìùëõùëìùîºsubscriptùëîùëöùëî\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}f_{n}=f,\quad\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}g_{m}=g.

Assume that f‚Äã(z)=0ùëìùëß0f(z)=0 whenever g‚Äã(z)=0ùëîùëß0g(z)=0. Consider the function

g~m‚âî(f/g)‚Äãgm.‚âîsubscript~ùëîùëöùëìùëîsubscriptùëîùëö\tilde{g}_{m}\coloneqq(f/g)g_{m}. (7.2)

Although g~msubscript~ùëîùëö\tilde{g}_{m} is supported on the sample drawn from density gùëîg, it provides an unbiased estimator of fùëìf:

ùîº‚Å°g~m=(f/g)‚Äãùîº‚Å°gm=(f/g)‚Äãg=f.ùîºsubscript~ùëîùëöùëìùëîùîºsubscriptùëîùëöùëìùëîùëîùëì\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\tilde{g}_{m}=(f/g)\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}g_{m}=(f/g)g=f.

This property will be crucial in the proof of Theorem¬†3.1.

Let us look at the low-degree projections of fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n} and g~msubscript~ùëîùëö\tilde{g}_{m} and try to bound their mean magnitude and deviation from the mean. Toward this end, note that

‚àÄx‚àà{‚àí1,1}p,‚à•(1x)‚â§d‚à•L2=(p‚â§d)1/2‚Äã12p.formulae-sequencefor-allùë•superscript11ùëùsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscript1ùë•absentùëësuperscriptùêø2superscriptbinomialùëùabsentùëë121superscript2ùëù\forall x\in\{-1,1\}^{p},\quad\mathinner{\!\bigl{\lVert}({\textbf{1}}_{x})^{\leq d}\bigr{\rVert}}_{L^{2}}=\binom{p}{\leq d}^{1/2}\frac{1}{2^{p}}. (7.3)

Indeed, to see this, use Parseval‚Äôs identity

‚à•(1x)‚â§d‚à•L22=‚àë|J|‚â§d‚ü®1x,wJ‚ü©L22=‚àë|J|‚â§d(12p‚ÄãwJ‚Äã(x))2superscriptsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscript1ùë•absentùëësuperscriptùêø22subscriptùêΩùëësuperscriptsubscriptsubscript1ùë•subscriptùë§ùêΩsuperscriptùêø22subscriptùêΩùëësuperscript1superscript2ùëùsubscriptùë§ùêΩùë•2\mathinner{\!\bigl{\lVert}({\textbf{1}}_{x})^{\leq d}\bigr{\rVert}}_{L^{2}}^{2}=\sum_{\mathinner{\!\left\lvert J\right\rvert}\leq d}\langle{\textbf{1}}_{x},w_{J}\rangle_{L^{2}}^{2}=\sum_{\mathinner{\!\left\lvert J\right\rvert}\leq d}\Big{(}\frac{1}{2^{p}}w_{J}(x)\Big{)}^{2}

and recall that the Walsh function wJsubscriptùë§ùêΩw_{J} takes ¬±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1 values. Furthermore, by definition of fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n} and the triangle inequality, (7.3) yields

‚à•(fn)‚â§d‚à•L2‚â§(p‚â§d)1/2‚Äã12pdeterministically.subscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùëìùëõabsentùëësuperscriptùêø2superscriptbinomialùëùabsentùëë121superscript2ùëùdeterministically\mathinner{\!\bigl{\lVert}(f_{n})^{\leq d}\bigr{\rVert}}_{L^{2}}\leq\binom{p}{\leq d}^{1/2}\frac{1}{2^{p}}\quad\text{deterministically}. (7.4)
Lemma 7.1 (Deviation).

We have

(ùîº‚Å°‚à•(fn‚àíf)‚â§d‚à•L22)1/2‚â§(p‚â§d)1/2‚Äã1n‚Äã2p.superscriptùîºsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùëìùëõùëìabsentùëësuperscriptùêø2212superscriptbinomialùëùabsentùëë121ùëõsuperscript2ùëù\left(\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\mathinner{\!\bigl{\lVert}(f_{n}-f)^{\leq d}\bigr{\rVert}}_{L^{2}}^{2}\right)^{1/2}\leq\binom{p}{\leq d}^{1/2}\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}2^{p}}.

Moreover, if ‚à•f/g‚à•L2‚â§Œ∫subscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëìùëîsuperscriptùêø2ùúÖ\mathinner{\!\left\lVert f/g\right\rVert}_{L^{2}}\leq\kappa then we have

(ùîº‚Å°‚à•(g~m‚àíf)‚â§d‚à•L2)1/2‚â§(p‚â§d)1/2‚ÄãŒ∫m‚Äã2p.superscriptùîºsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscript~ùëîùëöùëìabsentùëësuperscriptùêø212superscriptbinomialùëùabsentùëë12ùúÖùëösuperscript2ùëù\left(\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\mathinner{\!\bigl{\lVert}(\tilde{g}_{m}-f)^{\leq d}\bigr{\rVert}}_{L^{2}}\right)^{1/2}\leq\binom{p}{\leq d}^{1/2}\frac{\kappa}{\sqrt{m}2^{p}}.
Proof.

By Parseval‚Äôs identity,

‚à•(fn‚àíf)‚â§d‚à•L22=‚àë|J|‚â§d‚ü®fn‚àíf,wJ‚ü©L22.superscriptsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùëìùëõùëìabsentùëësuperscriptùêø22subscriptùêΩùëësuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùëìùëõùëìsubscriptùë§ùêΩsuperscriptùêø22\mathinner{\!\bigl{\lVert}(f_{n}-f)^{\leq d}\bigr{\rVert}}_{L^{2}}^{2}=\sum_{\mathinner{\!\left\lvert J\right\rvert}\leq d}\langle f_{n}-f,w_{J}\rangle_{L^{2}}^{2}. (7.5)

By definition (7.1) of fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n}, each term of this sum can be expressed as

‚ü®fn‚àíf,wJ‚ü©L2=1n‚Äã‚àëi=1n‚ü®1xi‚àíf,wJ‚ü©L2.subscriptsubscriptùëìùëõùëìsubscriptùë§ùêΩsuperscriptùêø21ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscriptsubscript1subscriptùë•ùëñùëìsubscriptùë§ùêΩsuperscriptùêø2\langle f_{n}-f,w_{J}\rangle_{L^{2}}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\langle{\textbf{1}}_{x_{i}}-f,w_{J}\rangle_{L^{2}}.

The terms on the right hand side are i.i.d. mean zero random variables, so

ùîº‚ü®fn‚àíf,wJ‚ü©L22\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\langle f_{n}-f,w_{J}\rangle_{L^{2}}^{2} =1nùîº‚ü®1x1‚àíf,wJ‚ü©L22\displaystyle=\frac{1}{n}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\langle{\textbf{1}}_{x_{1}}-f,w_{J}\rangle_{L^{2}}^{2}
‚â§1nùîº‚ü®1x1,wJ‚ü©L22(the variance is bounded by the second moment)\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{n}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\langle{\textbf{1}}_{x_{1}},w_{J}\rangle_{L^{2}}^{2}\quad\text{(the variance is bounded by the second moment)}
=1nùîº(12pwJ(x1))2=1n‚Äã22‚Äãp,\displaystyle=\frac{1}{n}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\Big{(}\frac{1}{2^{p}}w_{J}(x_{1})\Big{)}^{2}=\frac{1}{n2^{2p}},

since the Walsh function wJsubscriptùë§ùêΩw_{J} takes ¬±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1 values. Substitute this bound into Parseval‚Äôs identity (7.5) to get

ùîº‚Å°‚à•(fn‚àíf)‚â§d‚à•L22‚â§(p‚â§d)‚ãÖ1n‚Äã22‚Äãp.ùîºsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùëìùëõùëìabsentùëësuperscriptùêø22‚ãÖbinomialùëùabsentùëë1ùëõsuperscript22ùëù\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\mathinner{\!\bigl{\lVert}(f_{n}-f)^{\leq d}\bigr{\rVert}}_{L^{2}}^{2}\leq\binom{p}{\leq d}\cdot\frac{1}{n2^{2p}}.

This proves the first part of the lemma.

The second part of the lemma can be derived similarly. Indeed,

‚à•(g~m‚àíf)‚â§d‚à•L22=‚àë|J|‚â§d‚ü®g~m‚àíf,wJ‚ü©L22.superscriptsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscript~ùëîùëöùëìabsentùëësuperscriptùêø22subscriptùêΩùëësuperscriptsubscriptsubscript~ùëîùëöùëìsubscriptùë§ùêΩsuperscriptùêø22\mathinner{\!\bigl{\lVert}(\tilde{g}_{m}-f)^{\leq d}\bigr{\rVert}}_{L^{2}}^{2}=\sum_{\mathinner{\!\left\lvert J\right\rvert}\leq d}\langle\tilde{g}_{m}-f,w_{J}\rangle_{L^{2}}^{2}. (7.6)

By definition (7.1) of gmsubscriptùëîùëög_{m} and (7.2) of g~msubscript~ùëîùëö\tilde{g}_{m}, each term of this sum can be expressed as

‚ü®g~m‚àíf,wJ‚ü©L2=1m‚Äã‚àëi=1m‚ü®f‚Äã(yi)g‚Äã(yi)‚ãÖ1yi‚àíf,wJ‚ü©L2.subscriptsubscript~ùëîùëöùëìsubscriptùë§ùêΩsuperscriptùêø21ùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëösubscript‚ãÖùëìsubscriptùë¶ùëñùëîsubscriptùë¶ùëñsubscript1subscriptùë¶ùëñùëìsubscriptùë§ùêΩsuperscriptùêø2\langle\tilde{g}_{m}-f,w_{J}\rangle_{L^{2}}=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\Big{\langle}\frac{f(y_{i})}{g(y_{i})}\cdot{\textbf{1}}_{y_{i}}-f,w_{J}\Big{\rangle}_{L^{2}}.

The terms on the right hand side are i.i.d. mean zero random variables, so

ùîº‚ü®g~m‚àíf,wJ‚ü©L22\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\langle\tilde{g}_{m}-f,w_{J}\rangle_{L^{2}}^{2} =1mùîº‚ü®f‚Äã(y1)g‚Äã(y1)‚ãÖ1y1‚àíf,wJ‚ü©L22\displaystyle=\frac{1}{m}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\Big{\langle}\frac{f(y_{1})}{g(y_{1})}\cdot{\textbf{1}}_{y_{1}}-f,w_{J}\Big{\rangle}_{L^{2}}^{2}
‚â§1mùîº‚ü®f‚Äã(y1)g‚Äã(y1)‚ãÖ1y1,wJ‚ü©L22(the variance is bounded by the second moment)\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{m}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\Big{\langle}\frac{f(y_{1})}{g(y_{1})}\cdot{\textbf{1}}_{y_{1}},w_{J}\Big{\rangle}_{L^{2}}^{2}\quad\text{(the variance is bounded by the second moment)}
=1mùîº(12pf‚Äã(y1)g‚Äã(y1)wJ(y1))2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{m}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\Big{(}\frac{1}{2^{p}}\frac{f(y_{1})}{g(y_{1})}w_{J}(y_{1})\Big{)}^{2}

where in the last line we used the fact that the Walsh function wJsubscriptùë§ùêΩw_{J} takes ¬±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1 values and the assumption on f/gùëìùëîf/g. Substitute this bound into Parseval‚Äôs identity (7.6) to get

ùîº‚Å°‚à•(g~m‚àíf)‚â§d‚à•L22‚â§(p‚â§d)‚ãÖŒ∫2m‚Äã22‚Äãp.ùîºsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscript~ùëîùëöùëìabsentùëësuperscriptùêø22‚ãÖbinomialùëùabsentùëësuperscriptùúÖ2ùëösuperscript22ùëù\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\mathinner{\!\bigl{\lVert}(\tilde{g}_{m}-f)^{\leq d}\bigr{\rVert}}_{L^{2}}^{2}\leq\binom{p}{\leq d}\cdot\frac{\kappa^{2}}{m2^{2p}}.

This proves the second part of the lemma. ‚àé

8. Proof of Theorem¬†3.1

The following master theorem is a more general version of Theorem¬†3.1, as we will see shortly. Recall that gm,Œºm,g~msubscriptùëîùëösubscriptùúáùëösubscript~ùëîùëög_{m},\mu_{m},\tilde{g}_{m} are defined in (7.1).

Theorem 8.1.

Let fùëìf and gùëîg be densities on the cube {‚àí1,1}psuperscript11ùëù\{-1,1\}^{p}, and let fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n} and gmsubscriptùëîùëög_{m} be their empirical counterparts. Assume that ‚à•f/g‚à•L2‚â§Œ∫subscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëìùëîsuperscriptùêø2ùúÖ\mathinner{\!\left\lVert f/g\right\rVert}_{L^{2}}\leq\kappa for some Œ∫‚â•1ùúÖ1\kappa\geq 1 and that gùëîg is bounded below by Œ±/2pùõºsuperscript2ùëù\alpha/2^{p}. If n‚â•16‚Äã(Œ±‚ÄãŒ¥)‚àí2‚ÄãŒ≥‚àí1‚Äãe2‚Äãd‚Äã(p‚â§d)ùëõ16superscriptùõºùõø2superscriptùõæ1superscriptùëí2ùëëbinomialùëùabsentùëën\geq 16(\alpha\delta)^{-2}\gamma^{-1}e^{2d}\binom{p}{\leq d} and m‚â•16‚Äã(Œ±‚ÄãŒ¥)‚àí2‚ÄãŒ≥‚àí1‚ÄãŒ∫2‚Äãe2‚Äãd‚Äã(p‚â§d)ùëö16superscriptùõºùõø2superscriptùõæ1superscriptùúÖ2superscriptùëí2ùëëbinomialùëùabsentùëëm\geq 16(\alpha\delta)^{-2}\gamma^{-1}\kappa^{2}e^{2d}\binom{p}{\leq d} then the following holds with probability 1‚àí2‚ÄãŒ≥12ùõæ1-2\gamma. There exists h:{‚àí1,1}p‚Üí‚Ñù:‚Ñésuperscript11ùëù‚Üí‚Ñùh\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\{-1,1\}^{p}\to\mathbb{R} that satisfies

h‚â§d=fn‚â§d,supp‚Å°(h)‚äÇsupp‚Å°(gm),‚à•h‚àí(f/g)‚Äãgm‚à•‚àû‚â§Œ¥m.formulae-sequencesuperscript‚Ñéabsentùëësuperscriptsubscriptùëìùëõabsentùëëformulae-sequencesupp‚Ñésuppsubscriptùëîùëösubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚Ñéùëìùëîsubscriptùëîùëöùõøùëöh^{\leq d}=f_{n}^{\leq d},\quad\operatorname{supp}(h)\subset\operatorname{supp}(g_{m}),\quad\mathinner{\!\left\lVert h-(f/g)g_{m}\right\rVert}_{\infty}\leq\frac{\delta}{m}.
Proof.

Let g~m=(f/g)‚Äãgmsubscript~ùëîùëöùëìùëîsubscriptùëîùëö\tilde{g}_{m}=(f/g)g_{m} and apply Theorem¬†6.1 for the function F=fn‚àíg~mùêπsubscriptùëìùëõsubscript~ùëîùëöF=f_{n}-\tilde{g}_{m}. With probability 1‚àíŒ≥1ùõæ1-\gamma, there exists w‚ààW>dùë§superscriptùëäabsentùëëw\in W^{>d} such that

fn‚àíg~m‚àíw‚ààSŒºmand‚à•fn‚àíg~m‚àíw‚à•‚àû‚â§2‚Äãed‚Äã2pŒ±‚Äãm‚Äã‚à•(fn‚àíg~m)‚â§d‚à•L2.formulae-sequencesubscriptùëìùëõsubscript~ùëîùëöùë§subscriptùëÜsubscriptùúáùëöandsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùëìùëõsubscript~ùëîùëöùë§2superscriptùëíùëësuperscript2ùëùùõºùëösubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùëìùëõsubscript~ùëîùëöabsentùëësuperscriptùêø2f_{n}-\tilde{g}_{m}-w\in S_{\mu_{m}}\quad\text{and}\quad\mathinner{\!\left\lVert f_{n}-\tilde{g}_{m}-w\right\rVert}_{\infty}\leq\frac{2e^{d}2^{p}}{\alpha m}\mathinner{\!\bigl{\lVert}(f_{n}-\tilde{g}_{m})^{\leq d}\bigr{\rVert}}_{L^{2}}. (8.1)

Set

h=fn‚àíw.‚Ñésubscriptùëìùëõùë§h=f_{n}-w.

Since w‚ààW>dùë§superscriptùëäabsentùëëw\in W^{>d}, we have h‚â§d=fn‚â§dsuperscript‚Ñéabsentùëësuperscriptsubscriptùëìùëõabsentùëëh^{\leq d}=f_{n}^{\leq d} as claimed. Since both g~msubscript~ùëîùëö\tilde{g}_{m} and h‚àíg~m=fn‚àíg~m‚àíw‚Ñésubscript~ùëîùëösubscriptùëìùëõsubscript~ùëîùëöùë§h-\tilde{g}_{m}=f_{n}-\tilde{g}_{m}-w lie in SŒºmsubscriptùëÜsubscriptùúáùëöS_{\mu_{m}}, so does h‚Ñéh, as claimed.

Furthermore, combining both bounds of Lemma¬†7.1 via the Minkowski inequality, we get

(ùîº‚Å°‚à•(fn‚àíg~m)‚â§d‚à•L22)1/2‚â§(p‚â§d)1/2‚Äã(1n+Œ∫m)‚Äã12p.superscriptùîºsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùëìùëõsubscript~ùëîùëöabsentùëësuperscriptùêø2212superscriptbinomialùëùabsentùëë121ùëõùúÖùëö1superscript2ùëù\left(\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\mathinner{\!\bigl{\lVert}(f_{n}-\tilde{g}_{m})^{\leq d}\bigr{\rVert}}_{L^{2}}^{2}\right)^{1/2}\leq\binom{p}{\leq d}^{1/2}\Big{(}\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}+\frac{\kappa}{\sqrt{m}}\Big{)}\frac{1}{2^{p}}.

By Chebyshev‚Äôs inequality, with probability at least 1‚àíŒ≥1ùõæ1-\gamma we have

‚à•(fn‚àíg~m)‚â§d‚à•L2‚â§Œ≥‚àí1/2‚Äã(p‚â§d)1/2‚Äã(1n+Œ∫m)‚Äã12p.subscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùëìùëõsubscript~ùëîùëöabsentùëësuperscriptùêø2superscriptùõæ12superscriptbinomialùëùabsentùëë121ùëõùúÖùëö1superscript2ùëù\mathinner{\!\bigl{\lVert}(f_{n}-\tilde{g}_{m})^{\leq d}\bigr{\rVert}}_{L^{2}}\leq\gamma^{-1/2}\binom{p}{\leq d}^{1/2}\Big{(}\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}+\frac{\kappa}{\sqrt{m}}\Big{)}\frac{1}{2^{p}}.

We substitute this into¬†(8.1) and get

‚à•h‚àíg~m‚à•L‚àû‚Äã(ŒΩm)‚â§2‚Äãed‚Äã2pŒ±‚Äãm‚ãÖŒ≥‚àí1/2‚Äã(p‚â§d)1/2‚Äã(1n+Œ∫m)‚Äã12p‚â§Œ¥m,subscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚Ñésubscript~ùëîùëösuperscriptùêøsubscriptùúàùëö‚ãÖ2superscriptùëíùëësuperscript2ùëùùõºùëösuperscriptùõæ12superscriptbinomialùëùabsentùëë121ùëõùúÖùëö1superscript2ùëùùõøùëö\mathinner{\!\left\lVert h-\tilde{g}_{m}\right\rVert}_{L^{\infty}(\nu_{m})}\leq\frac{2e^{d}2^{p}}{\alpha m}\cdot\gamma^{-1/2}\binom{p}{\leq d}^{1/2}\Big{(}\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}+\frac{\kappa}{\sqrt{m}}\Big{)}\frac{1}{2^{p}}\leq\frac{\delta}{m},

where we used the assumption on nùëõn and mùëöm in the last bound. ‚àé

8.1. Proof of Theorem¬†3.1

Let us explain how Theorem¬†8.1 is a more general form of Theorem¬†3.1. Let fùëìf and gùëîg be the densities of the two distributions in the statement of Theorem¬†3.1, X=(x1,‚Ä¶,xn)ùëãsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõX=(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}) and S=(y1,‚Ä¶,ym)ùëÜsubscriptùë¶1‚Ä¶subscriptùë¶ùëöS=(y_{1},\ldots,y_{m}) be the samples drawn according to these densities, and fn=1n‚Äã‚àëi=1n1xisubscriptùëìùëõ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscript1subscriptùë•ùëñf_{n}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\textbf{1}}_{x_{i}} and gm=1m‚Äã‚àëi=1m1yisubscriptùëîùëö1ùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëösubscript1subscriptùë¶ùëñg_{m}=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}{\textbf{1}}_{y_{i}} be the empirical densities. The regularity assumption implies that

f/g‚âç1pointwise,asymptotically-equalsùëìùëî1pointwisef/g\asymp 1\quad\text{pointwise}, (8.2)

and in particular the requirement ‚à•f/g‚à•L2=O‚Äã(1)subscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëìùëîsuperscriptùêø2ùëÇ1\mathinner{\!\left\lVert f/g\right\rVert}_{L^{2}}=O(1) holds in Theorem¬†8.1. The function h‚Ñéh we obtain from that result is supported on S=supp‚Å°(gm)ùëÜsuppsubscriptùëîùëöS=\operatorname{supp}(g_{m}) and satisfies

h‚â•(f/g)‚Äãgm‚àíŒ¥m‚â≥1meverywhere on¬†S.formulae-sequence‚Ñéùëìùëîsubscriptùëîùëöùõøùëögreater-than-or-equivalent-to1ùëöeverywhere on¬†Sh\geq(f/g)g_{m}-\frac{\delta}{m}\gtrsim\frac{1}{m}\quad\text{everywhere on $S$}.

(In the last step we used (8.2) that gm=1m‚Äã‚àëi=1m1yisubscriptùëîùëö1ùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëösubscript1subscriptùë¶ùëñg_{m}=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}{\textbf{1}}_{y_{i}} is lower bounded by 1/m1ùëö1/m on SùëÜS.) In particular, h‚Ñéh is positive on SùëÜS. The condition h‚â§d=fn‚â§dsuperscript‚Ñéabsentùëësuperscriptsubscriptùëìùëõabsentùëëh^{\leq d}=f_{n}^{\leq d} means that h‚Ñéh has exactly the same marginals up to dimension dùëëd as fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n}, the uniform probability distribution on XùëãX. Since fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n} is a density, the sum of all of its values equals 111. The same must be true for h‚Ñéh, since the sum of the values can be expressed as the zero-dimensional marginal, which must be the same for h‚Ñéh and fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n}. In other words, h‚Ñéh must be a density, too. Theorem¬†3.1 is proved. ‚àé

8.2. A one-sample version

Here is a one-sample version of Theorem¬†8.1. It is a rigorous version of Theorem¬†3.6 we stated informally in the introduction.

Theorem 8.2.

Let fùëìf be a density on the cube {‚àí1,1}psuperscript11ùëù\{-1,1\}^{p} that is bounded below by Œ±/2pùõºsuperscript2ùëù\alpha/2^{p}, and let fmsubscriptùëìùëöf_{m} be its empirical counterpart. If m‚â•16‚Äã(Œ±‚ÄãŒ¥)‚àí2‚ÄãŒ≥‚àí1‚Äãe2‚Äãd‚Äã(p‚â§d)ùëö16superscriptùõºùõø2superscriptùõæ1superscriptùëí2ùëëbinomialùëùabsentùëëm\geq 16(\alpha\delta)^{-2}\gamma^{-1}e^{2d}\binom{p}{\leq d} then the following holds with probability 1‚àí2‚ÄãŒ≥12ùõæ1-2\gamma. There exists a density h‚Ñéh on supp‚Å°(fm)suppsubscriptùëìùëö\operatorname{supp}(f_{m}) that satisfies

h‚â§d=f‚â§d,‚à•h‚àífm‚à•‚àû‚â§Œ¥m.formulae-sequencesuperscript‚Ñéabsentùëësuperscriptùëìabsentùëësubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚Ñésubscriptùëìùëöùõøùëöh^{\leq d}=f^{\leq d},\quad\mathinner{\!\left\lVert h-f_{m}\right\rVert}_{\infty}\leq\frac{\delta}{m}.
Proof.

The proof is similar to that of Theorem¬†3.1 above. Choose g=fùëîùëìg=f, n=mùëõùëön=m, hence g~m=(f/g)‚Äãgm=fmsubscript~ùëîùëöùëìùëîsubscriptùëîùëösubscriptùëìùëö\tilde{g}_{m}=(f/g)g_{m}=f_{m}, and use F=f‚àíg~mùêπùëìsubscript~ùëîùëöF=f-\tilde{g}_{m}. Apply only the first bound in Lemma¬†7.1.

Note that the bound in the conclusion and the fact that fm=1/msubscriptùëìùëö1ùëöf_{m}=1/m on its support implies that h‚â•1/m‚àíŒ¥/m>0‚Ñé1ùëöùõøùëö0h\geq 1/m-\delta/m>0 on supp‚Å°(fm)suppsubscriptùëìùëö\operatorname{supp}(f_{m}), and thus h‚Ñéh is a density.

We leave the details to the reader. ‚àé

9. Solution space

Our next focus is on proving Theorem¬†3.5, which gives guarantees for privacy and accuracy of the synthetic data created by Algorithm¬†1.

Let us formally introduce the solution space ‚Äì the space of all functions on the reduced sample space SùëÜS that have the same marginals as a given function uùë¢u.

Definition 9.1 (Solution space).

Let Œºùúá\mu be a probability measure on the cube {‚àí1,1}psuperscript11ùëù\{-1,1\}^{p}, and Œºmsubscriptùúáùëö\mu_{m} be its empirical counterpart. For any function u:{‚àí1,1}p‚Üí‚Ñù:ùë¢superscript11ùëù‚Üí‚Ñùu\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\{-1,1\}^{p}\to\mathbb{R}, consider the affine subspace H‚Äã(u)ùêªùë¢H(u) of all functions supported on supp‚Å°(Œºm)suppsubscriptùúáùëö\operatorname{supp}(\mu_{m}) and that have the same marginals up to dimension dùëëd as the function uùë¢u, i.e.

H‚Äã(u)‚âî{h‚ààSŒºm:h‚â§d=u‚â§d}=(u‚àíW>d)‚à©SŒºm,‚âîùêªùë¢‚ÑésubscriptùëÜsubscriptùúáùëö:superscript‚Ñéabsentùëësuperscriptùë¢absentùëëùë¢superscriptùëäabsentùëësubscriptùëÜsubscriptùúáùëöH(u)\coloneqq\left\{h\in S_{\mu_{m}}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\;h^{\leq d}=u^{\leq d}\right\}=\left(u-W^{>d}\right)\cap S_{\mu_{m}},

where SŒºmsubscriptùëÜsubscriptùúáùëöS_{\mu_{m}}, as before, denotes the linear space of all functions supported on the reduced space S=supp‚Å°(Œºm)ùëÜsuppsubscriptùúáùëöS=\operatorname{supp}(\mu_{m}).

9.1. Success with high probability

The Algorithm¬†1 succeeds, i.e. does not return ‚ÄúFailure‚Äù, when the reduced space S={Œ∏1,‚Ä¶,Œ∏m}ùëÜsubscriptùúÉ1‚Ä¶subscriptùúÉùëöS=\{\theta_{1},\ldots,\theta_{m}\} is well conditioned. By definition, this happens if

smin‚Äã(M)‚â•m2‚Äãedsubscriptùë†ùëÄùëö2superscriptùëíùëës_{\min}(M)\geq\frac{\sqrt{m}}{2e^{d}} (9.1)

where sminsubscriptùë†s_{\min} denotes the smallest singular value, and MùëÄM is the m√ó(p‚â§d)ùëöbinomialùëùabsentùëëm\times\binom{p}{\leq d} matrix whose entries are wJ‚Äã(Œ∏i)subscriptùë§ùêΩsubscriptùúÉùëñw_{J}(\theta_{i}) for |J|‚â§dùêΩùëë\mathinner{\!\left\lvert J\right\rvert}\leq d, i.e. the matrix whose rows are indexed by the points Œ∏i‚ààSsubscriptùúÉùëñùëÜ\theta_{i}\in S, and whose columns are indexed by Walsh functions wJsubscriptùë§ùêΩw_{J} of degree at most dùëëd.

Let us reformulate the condition (9.1) in the dual form, and then deduce from Theorem¬†6.1 that that it holds with high probability.

Lemma 9.2 (Well conditioned reduced space).

The reduced space SùëÜS is well conditioned if and only if any function F:{‚àí1,1}p‚Üí‚Ñù:ùêπsuperscript11ùëù‚Üí‚ÑùF\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\{-1,1\}^{p}\to\mathbb{R} satisfies

inf{‚à•F‚àíw‚à•L2‚Äã(Œºm):w‚ààW>d,F‚àíw‚ààSŒºm}‚â§2‚Äãed‚Äã2pm‚à•F‚â§d‚à•L2.\inf\left\{\mathinner{\!\left\lVert F-w\right\rVert}_{L^{2}(\mu_{m})}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\;w\in W^{>d},\,F-w\in S_{\mu_{m}}\right\}\leq\frac{2e^{d}2^{p}}{m}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert F^{\leq d}\right\rVert}_{L^{2}}. (9.2)
Proof.

Decomposing F=F‚â§d+F>dùêπsuperscriptùêπabsentùëësuperscriptùêπabsentùëëF=F^{\leq d}+F^{>d} we see that F‚â§dsuperscriptùêπabsentùëëF^{\leq d} in the right hand side of (9.2) may be replaced by FùêπF without loss of generality. Furthermore, since ‚à•f‚à•L2‚Äã(Œºm)=2p/m‚Äã‚à•f‚à•L2subscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëìsuperscriptùêø2subscriptùúáùëösuperscript2ùëùùëösubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëìsuperscriptùêø2\mathinner{\!\left\lVert f\right\rVert}_{L^{2}(\mu_{m})}=\sqrt{2^{p}/m}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert f\right\rVert}_{L^{2}} for any f‚ààSŒºmùëìsubscriptùëÜsubscriptùúáùëöf\in S_{\mu_{m}}, we can rewrite condition (9.2) equivalently as

inf{‚à•F‚àíw‚à•L2:w‚ààW>d,F‚àíw‚ààSŒºm}‚â§B‚à•F‚à•L2\inf\left\{\mathinner{\!\left\lVert F-w\right\rVert}_{L^{2}}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\;w\in W^{>d},\,F-w\in S_{\mu_{m}}\right\}\leq B\mathinner{\!\left\lVert F\right\rVert}_{L^{2}} (9.3)

where

B=2‚Äãed‚Äã2pm.ùêµ2superscriptùëíùëësuperscript2ùëùùëöB=2e^{d}\sqrt{\frac{2^{p}}{m}}.

We will employ a duality argument similar to the one we used in the proof of Theorem¬†6.1. Given Œ¥>0ùõø0\delta>0, consider the weighted Hilbert space LŒ¥2subscriptsuperscriptùêø2ùõøL^{2}_{\delta} where the norm is defined by

‚à•F‚à•LŒ¥22‚âî‚à•F‚Äã1S‚à•L22+Œ¥‚Äã‚à•F‚Äã1Sc‚à•L22.‚âîsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùêπsubscriptsuperscriptùêø2ùõø2superscriptsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùêπsubscript1ùëÜsuperscriptùêø22ùõøsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùêπsubscript1superscriptùëÜùëêsuperscriptùêø22\mathinner{\!\left\lVert F\right\rVert}_{L^{2}_{\delta}}^{2}\coloneqq\mathinner{\!\left\lVert F{\textbf{1}}_{S}\right\rVert}_{L^{2}}^{2}+\delta\mathinner{\!\left\lVert F{\textbf{1}}_{S^{c}}\right\rVert}_{L^{2}}^{2}.

where 1Ssubscript1ùëÜ{\textbf{1}}_{S} denotes the indicator function of SùëÜS. Then (9.3) is equivalent to

inf{‚à•F‚àíw‚à•L1/Œ¥2:w‚ààW>d}‚â§B‚Äã‚à•F‚à•L2‚àÄŒ¥>0.formulae-sequenceinfimum:subscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùêπùë§subscriptsuperscriptùêø21ùõøùë§superscriptùëäabsentùëëùêµsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùêπsuperscriptùêø2for-allùõø0\inf\left\{\mathinner{\!\left\lVert F-w\right\rVert}_{L^{2}_{1/\delta}}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\;w\in W^{>d}\right\}\leq B\mathinner{\!\left\lVert F\right\rVert}_{L^{2}}\quad\forall\delta>0.

(To see this, note that taking Œ¥‚Üí0+‚Üíùõøsubscript0\delta\to 0_{+} enforces F‚àíw‚Äã1Sc=0ùêπùë§subscript1superscriptùëÜùëê0F-w{\textbf{1}}_{S^{c}}=0, or equivalently F‚àíw‚ààSŒºmùêπùë§subscriptùëÜsubscriptùúáùëöF-w\in S_{\mu_{m}}.) This can be interpreted as a bound on the norm of the quotient map QùëÑQ:

‚à•Q:L2‚ÜíL1/Œ¥2/W>d‚à•‚â§B‚àÄŒ¥>0.formulae-sequencedelimited-‚à•‚à•:ùëÑsuperscriptùêø2‚Üísubscriptsuperscriptùêø21ùõøsuperscriptùëäabsentùëëùêµfor-allùõø0\mathinner{\!\left\lVert Q\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\;L^{2}\to L^{2}_{1/\delta}/W^{>d}\right\rVert}\leq B\quad\forall\delta>0.

Let us dualize this bound. The adjoint operator has the same norm, so

‚à•Q‚àó:(L2)‚àó‚Üí(L1/Œ¥2/W>d)‚àó‚à•‚â§B‚àÄŒ¥>0.formulae-sequencedelimited-‚à•‚à•:superscriptùëÑsuperscriptsuperscriptùêø2‚Üísuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùêø21ùõøsuperscriptùëäabsentùëëùêµfor-allùõø0\mathinner{\!\left\lVert Q^{*}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\;\big{(}L^{2}\big{)}^{*}\to\big{(}L^{2}_{1/\delta}/W^{>d}\big{)}^{*}\right\rVert}\leq B\quad\forall\delta>0.

The adjoint of the quotient map is the canonical (identity) embedding; the Hilbert space L2superscriptùêø2L^{2} is self-dual, and the dual of a quotient space is a subspace of the dual, i.e.

(L1/Œ¥2/W>d)‚àó=((W>d)‚üÇ,‚à•‚à•(L1/Œ¥2)‚àó)=(W‚â§d,‚à•‚à•LŒ¥2).\big{(}L^{2}_{1/\delta}/W^{>d}\big{)}^{*}=((W^{>d})^{\perp},\|\,\|_{(L^{2}_{1/\delta})^{*}})=(W^{\leq d},\|\,\|_{L^{2}_{\delta}}).

Thus, the bound is equivalent to

‚à•Id:(W‚â§d,‚à•‚à•LŒ¥2)‚ÜíL2‚à•‚â§B‚àÄŒ¥>0.\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mathrm{Id}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\;(W^{\leq d},\|\,\|_{L^{2}_{\delta}})\to L^{2}\right\rVert}\leq B\quad\forall\delta>0.

By definition of the operator norm and the norm in LŒ¥2subscriptsuperscriptùêø2ùõøL^{2}_{\delta}, this bound is equivalent to saying that

Proposition 9.3 (Success with high probability).

If m‚â•16‚ÄãŒ≥‚àí2‚Äãe2‚Äãd‚Äã(p‚â§d)ùëö16superscriptùõæ2superscriptùëí2ùëëbinomialùëùabsentùëëm\geq 16\gamma^{-2}e^{2d}\binom{p}{\leq d}, then Algorithm¬†1 succeeds (i.e. does not return ‚ÄúFailure‚Äù) with probability at least 1‚àíŒ≥1ùõæ1-\gamma.

Proof.

By definition, Algorithm¬†1 succeeds if the reduced space SùëÜS is well conditioned. Then the conclusion immediately follows from Theorem¬†6.1 for the uniform density Œºùúá\mu, Lemma¬†9.2 and the fact that the L2‚Äã(Œºm)superscriptùêø2subscriptùúáùëöL^{2}(\mu_{m}) norm is bounded by the sup-norm. ‚àé

9.2. All solution spaces are translates of each other

First let us show that with high probability in Œºmsubscriptùúáùëö\mu_{m}, all solution spaces H‚Äã(u)ùêªùë¢H(u) are nonempty and are translates of each other. The following elementary lemma will help us.

Proposition 9.4.

If the reduced space SùëÜS is well conditioned, the solution spaces H‚Äã(u)ùêªùë¢H(u) for all u:{‚àí1,1}p‚Üí‚Ñù:ùë¢superscript11ùëù‚Üí‚Ñùu\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\{-1,1\}^{p}\to\mathbb{R} are nonempty and are translates of each other.

9.3. Sensitivity of the solution space

Next, we will check that the map u‚Ü¶H‚Äã(u)maps-toùë¢ùêªùë¢u\mapsto H(u) is Lipschitz in the Hausdorff metric. Recall that the Hausdorff distance between two subsets Aùê¥A and BùêµB of a normed space XùëãX is defined as

dX‚Äã(A,B)=max‚Å°{supa‚ààAinfb‚ààB‚à•a‚àíb‚à•X,supb‚ààBinfa‚ààA‚à•a‚àíb‚à•X}.subscriptùëëùëãùê¥ùêµsubscriptsupremumùëéùê¥subscriptinfimumùëèùêµsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëéùëèùëãsubscriptsupremumùëèùêµsubscriptinfimumùëéùê¥subscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëéùëèùëãd_{X}(A,B)=\max\left\{\sup_{a\in A}\inf_{b\in B}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert a-b\right\rVert}_{X},\,\sup_{b\in B}\inf_{a\in A}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert a-b\right\rVert}_{X}\right\}.

When Aùê¥A and BùêµB are affine subspaces that are translates of each other, we have

dX‚Äã(A,B)=infb‚ààB‚à•a‚àíb‚à•X=distX‚Å°(a,B)for any¬†‚Äãa‚ààA.formulae-sequencesubscriptùëëùëãùê¥ùêµsubscriptinfimumùëèùêµsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëéùëèùëãsubscriptdistùëãùëéùêµfor any¬†ùëéùê¥d_{X}(A,B)=\inf_{b\in B}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert a-b\right\rVert}_{X}=\operatorname{dist}_{X}(a,B)\quad\text{for any }a\in A.

When the norm is clear from the context, we skip the subscript XùëãX. When X=LqùëãsuperscriptùêøùëûX=L^{q} we simply write dq‚Äã(A,B)subscriptùëëùëûùê¥ùêµd_{q}(A,B).

10. Selection rule

Next, we want to extend sensitivity to the selection rule. Can we pick one point from a solution space in such a way that a small change in the solution space always leads to a small change in the selected point?

10.1. L2superscriptùêø2L^{2} sensitivity

We do not know the best selection rule in the L‚àûsuperscriptùêøL^{\infty} metric. The problem is simpler for the L2superscriptùêø2L^{2} metric: the proximal point (to a given reference point) is a good selection rule.

Lemma 10.1 (Sensitivity of the closest point in the Hilbert space).

Consider a Hilbert space XùëãX and a reference point r‚ààXùëüùëãr\in X. Let x‚Äã(K)ùë•ùêæx(K) denote a point in a nonempty closed set K‚äÇXùêæùëãK\subset X that is closest to rùëür, i.e.

10.2. Restriction onto the cube

Functions that comprise the solution space H‚Äã(u)ùêªùë¢H(u) may take negative values, hence not all of H‚Äã(u)ùêªùë¢H(u) consists of densities. 10.3. L‚àûsuperscriptùêøL^{\infty} sensitivity of the selection rule

Lemma 10.4 (L‚àûsuperscriptùêøL^{\infty} sensitivity of the selection rule).

Proof.

11. Shrinkage

Another step of Algorithm¬†1 we need to control is shrinkage. We will check here that shrinkage onto a cube is Lipschitz in the L‚àûsuperscriptùêøL^{\infty}-Hausdorff metric. Let us start with a general observation:

Lemma 11.1 (Shrinkage).

Let XùëãX be a normed space and z‚ààXùëßùëãz\in X be a point such that ‚à•z‚à•‚â§1‚àíŒ≤delimited-‚à•‚à•ùëß1ùõΩ\mathinner{\!\left\lVert z\right\rVert}\leq 1-\beta for some Œ≤‚àà(0,1)ùõΩ01\beta\in(0,1). Let r:X‚ÜíX:ùëüùëã‚Üíùëãr\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}X\to X be the retraction map onto the unit ball of XùëãX toward zùëßz, i.e.

r‚Äã(x)=(1‚àíŒª)‚Äãx+Œª‚Äãzùëüùë•1ùúÜùë•ùúÜùëßr(x)=(1-\lambda)x+\lambda z

where Œª=Œª‚Äã(x)ùúÜùúÜùë•\lambda=\lambda(x) is the minimal number in [0,1]01[0,1] such that ‚à•r‚Äã(x)‚à•‚â§1delimited-‚à•‚à•ùëüùë•1\mathinner{\!\left\lVert r(x)\right\rVert}\leq 1. Then the Lipschitz norm of the map Œª‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùúÜ‚ãÖ\lambda(\cdot) is at most 1/Œ≤1ùõΩ1/\beta, and the Lipschitz norm of the map r‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùëü‚ãÖr(\cdot) is at most 2/Œ≤2ùõΩ2/\beta.

Proof.

Fix any pair of vectors x1,x2‚ààXsubscriptùë•1subscriptùë•2ùëãx_{1},x_{2}\in X and denote

Œª1=Œª‚Äã(x1),Œª2=Œª‚Äã(x2),Œº=‚à•x1‚àíx2‚à•/Œ≤.formulae-sequencesubscriptùúÜ1ùúÜsubscriptùë•1formulae-sequencesubscriptùúÜ2ùúÜsubscriptùë•2ùúádelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë•1subscriptùë•2ùõΩ\lambda_{1}=\lambda(x_{1}),\quad\lambda_{2}=\lambda(x_{2}),\quad\mu=\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x_{1}-x_{2}\right\rVert}/\beta.

The claim about the Lipschitz norm of Œª‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùúÜ‚ãÖ\lambda(\cdot) can be stated as |Œª1‚àíŒª2|‚â§ŒºsubscriptùúÜ1subscriptùúÜ2ùúá\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\lambda_{1}-\lambda_{2}\right\rvert}\leq\mu. By symmetry, it suffices to show that

Œª1‚â§Œª2+Œº.subscriptùúÜ1subscriptùúÜ2ùúá\lambda_{1}\leq\lambda_{2}+\mu. (11.1)

This bound is trivial if Œª2+Œº>1subscriptùúÜ2ùúá1\lambda_{2}+\mu>1 since we always have Œª1‚â§1subscriptùúÜ11\lambda_{1}\leq 1. So we can assume from now on that Œª2+Œº‚àà[0,1]subscriptùúÜ2ùúá01\lambda_{2}+\mu\in[0,1].

Due to the minimality property in the definition of Œª1=Œª‚Äã(x1)subscriptùúÜ1ùúÜsubscriptùë•1\lambda_{1}=\lambda(x_{1}), in order to prove (11.1) it suffices to show that

‚à•(1‚àíŒª2‚àíŒº)‚Äãx1+(Œª2+Œº)‚Äãz‚à•‚â§1.delimited-‚à•‚à•1subscriptùúÜ2ùúásubscriptùë•1subscriptùúÜ2ùúáùëß1\mathinner{\!\left\lVert(1-\lambda_{2}-\mu)x_{1}+(\lambda_{2}+\mu)z\right\rVert}\leq 1. (11.2)

By triangle inequality, the left hand side is bounded by ‚à•A‚à•+‚à•B‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•ùê¥delimited-‚à•‚à•ùêµ\mathinner{\!\left\lVert A\right\rVert}+\mathinner{\!\left\lVert B\right\rVert} where

A=(1‚àíŒª2‚àíŒº)‚Äãx2+(Œª2+Œº)‚Äãz,B=(1‚àíŒª2‚àíŒº)‚Äã(x1‚àíx2).formulae-sequenceùê¥1subscriptùúÜ2ùúásubscriptùë•2subscriptùúÜ2ùúáùëßùêµ1subscriptùúÜ2ùúásubscriptùë•1subscriptùë•2A=(1-\lambda_{2}-\mu)x_{2}+(\lambda_{2}+\mu)z,\quad B=(1-\lambda_{2}-\mu)(x_{1}-x_{2}).

Rearranging the terms, we can rewrite

A=(1‚àía)‚Äã[(1‚àíŒª2)‚Äãx2+Œª2‚Äãz]+a‚Äãzwherea=Œº1‚àíŒª2.formulae-sequenceùê¥1ùëédelimited-[]1subscriptùúÜ2subscriptùë•2subscriptùúÜ2ùëßùëéùëßwhereùëéùúá1subscriptùúÜ2A=(1-a)\left[(1-\lambda_{2})x_{2}+\lambda_{2}z\right]+az\quad\text{where}\quad a=\frac{\mu}{1-\lambda_{2}}.

By assumption, a‚àà[0,1]ùëé01a\in[0,1]. Then Aùê¥A is a convex combination of the vector (1‚àíŒª2)‚Äãx2+Œª2‚Äãz1subscriptùúÜ2subscriptùë•2subscriptùúÜ2ùëß(1-\lambda_{2})x_{2}+\lambda_{2}z whose norm is bounded by 111 by definition of Œª2=Œª‚Äã(x2)subscriptùúÜ2ùúÜsubscriptùë•2\lambda_{2}=\lambda(x_{2}) and the vector zùëßz whose norm is bounded by 1‚àíŒ≤1ùõΩ1-\beta by assumption. Hence, by triangle inequality and definition of aùëéa and Œºùúá\mu, we have

‚à•A‚à•‚â§(1‚àía)‚ãÖ1+a‚ãÖ(1‚àíŒ≤)=1‚àía‚ÄãŒ≤‚â§1‚àíŒº‚ÄãŒ≤=1‚àí‚à•x1‚àíx2‚à•.delimited-‚à•‚à•ùê¥‚ãÖ1ùëé1‚ãÖùëé1ùõΩ1ùëéùõΩ1ùúáùõΩ1delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë•1subscriptùë•2\mathinner{\!\left\lVert A\right\rVert}\leq(1-a)\cdot 1+a\cdot(1-\beta)=1-a\beta\leq 1-\mu\beta=1-\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x_{1}-x_{2}\right\rVert}.

Furthermore, the assumption 1‚àíŒª2‚àíŒº‚àà[0,1]1subscriptùúÜ2ùúá011-\lambda_{2}-\mu\in[0,1] yields

‚à•B‚à•‚â§‚à•x1‚àíx2‚à•.delimited-‚à•‚à•ùêµdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë•1subscriptùë•2\mathinner{\!\left\lVert B\right\rVert}\leq\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x_{1}-x_{2}\right\rVert}.

Hence we showed that ‚à•A‚à•+‚à•B‚à•‚â§1delimited-‚à•‚à•ùê¥delimited-‚à•‚à•ùêµ1\mathinner{\!\left\lVert A\right\rVert}+\mathinner{\!\left\lVert B\right\rVert}\leq 1, establishing (11.2) and completing the first part of the proof (about the Lipschitz norm of ŒªùúÜ\lambda).

To prove the second part of the lemma, we need to show that

‚à•r‚Äã(x1)‚àír‚Äã(x2)‚à•‚â§(2/Œ≤)‚Äã‚à•x1‚àíx2‚à•.delimited-‚à•‚à•ùëüsubscriptùë•1ùëüsubscriptùë•22ùõΩdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë•1subscriptùë•2\mathinner{\!\left\lVert r(x_{1})-r(x_{2})\right\rVert}\leq(2/\beta)\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x_{1}-x_{2}\right\rVert}. (11.3)

Let us first prove this inequality assuming that ‚à•x1‚à•‚â§1delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë•11\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x_{1}\right\rVert}\leq 1 or ‚à•x2‚à•‚â§1delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë•21\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x_{2}\right\rVert}\leq 1. Without loss of generality, assume ‚à•x1‚à•‚â§1delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë•11\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x_{1}\right\rVert}\leq 1. Denoting Œº1=1‚àíŒª1subscriptùúá11subscriptùúÜ1\mu_{1}=1-\lambda_{1} and Œº2=1‚àíŒª2subscriptùúá21subscriptùúÜ2\mu_{2}=1-\lambda_{2} and using triangle inequality, we obtain

‚à•r‚Äã(x1)‚àír‚Äã(x2)‚à•=‚à•Œº1‚Äãx1+Œª1‚Äãz‚àíŒº2‚Äãx2‚àíŒª2‚Äãz‚à•‚â§‚à•Œº1‚Äãx1‚àíŒº2‚Äãx2‚à•+|Œª1‚àíŒª2|‚Äã‚à•z‚à•delimited-‚à•‚à•ùëüsubscriptùë•1ùëüsubscriptùë•2delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùúá1subscriptùë•1subscriptùúÜ1ùëßsubscriptùúá2subscriptùë•2subscriptùúÜ2ùëßdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùúá1subscriptùë•1subscriptùúá2subscriptùë•2subscriptùúÜ1subscriptùúÜ2delimited-‚à•‚à•ùëß\mathinner{\!\left\lVert r(x_{1})-r(x_{2})\right\rVert}=\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mu_{1}x_{1}+\lambda_{1}z-\mu_{2}x_{2}-\lambda_{2}z\right\rVert}\leq\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mu_{1}x_{1}-\mu_{2}x_{2}\right\rVert}+\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\lambda_{1}-\lambda_{2}\right\rvert}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert z\right\rVert} (11.4)

By the first part of the lemma and since ‚à•z‚à•‚â§1‚àíŒ≤delimited-‚à•‚à•ùëß1ùõΩ\mathinner{\!\left\lVert z\right\rVert}\leq 1-\beta, we have

|Œª1‚àíŒª2|‚Äã‚à•z‚à•‚â§1Œ≤‚Äã‚à•x1‚àíx2‚à•‚Äã(1‚àíŒ≤)=(1/Œ≤‚àí1)‚Äã‚à•x1‚àíx2‚à•.subscriptùúÜ1subscriptùúÜ2delimited-‚à•‚à•ùëß1ùõΩdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë•1subscriptùë•21ùõΩ1ùõΩ1delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë•1subscriptùë•2\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\lambda_{1}-\lambda_{2}\right\rvert}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert z\right\rVert}\leq\frac{1}{\beta}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x_{1}-x_{2}\right\rVert}(1-\beta)=(1/\beta-1)\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x_{1}-x_{2}\right\rVert}. (11.5)

Furthermore, adding and subtracting the cross term Œº2‚Äãx1subscriptùúá2subscriptùë•1\mu_{2}x_{1} and using triangle inequality, we get

‚à•Œº1‚Äãx1‚àíŒº2‚Äãx2‚à•‚â§|Œº1‚àíŒº2|‚Äã‚à•x1‚à•+Œº2‚Äã‚à•x1‚àíx2‚à•.delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùúá1subscriptùë•1subscriptùúá2subscriptùë•2subscriptùúá1subscriptùúá2delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë•1subscriptùúá2delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë•1subscriptùë•2\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mu_{1}x_{1}-\mu_{2}x_{2}\right\rVert}\leq\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mu_{1}-\mu_{2}\right\rvert}\,\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x_{1}\right\rVert}+\mu_{2}\,\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x_{1}-x_{2}\right\rVert}.

Now, |Œº1‚àíŒº2|=|Œª1‚àíŒª2|‚â§‚à•x1‚àíx2‚à•/Œ≤subscriptùúá1subscriptùúá2subscriptùúÜ1subscriptùúÜ2delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë•1subscriptùë•2ùõΩ\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\mu_{1}-\mu_{2}\right\rvert}=\mathinner{\!\left\lvert\lambda_{1}-\lambda_{2}\right\rvert}\leq\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x_{1}-x_{2}\right\rVert}/\beta by the first part of the lemma; ‚à•x1‚à•‚â§1delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë•11\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x_{1}\right\rVert}\leq 1 by the standing assumption, and Œº2‚â§1subscriptùúá21\mu_{2}\leq 1. Hence

‚à•Œº1‚Äãx1‚àíŒº2‚Äãx2‚à•‚â§(1/Œ≤+1)‚Äã‚à•x1‚àíx2‚à•.delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùúá1subscriptùë•1subscriptùúá2subscriptùë•21ùõΩ1delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë•1subscriptùë•2\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\mu_{1}x_{1}-\mu_{2}x_{2}\right\rVert}\leq(1/\beta+1)\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x_{1}-x_{2}\right\rVert}. (11.6)

Substitute (11.5) and (11.6) into (11.4), we conclude the claim (11.3).

Finally, consider the remaining case where both ‚à•x1‚à•‚â•1delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë•11\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x_{1}\right\rVert}\geq 1 and ‚à•x2‚à•‚â•1delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë•21\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x_{2}\right\rVert}\geq 1. Without loss of generality, Œª1‚â§Œª2subscriptùúÜ1subscriptùúÜ2\lambda_{1}\leq\lambda_{2}, so the vectors

x~1‚âî(1‚àíŒª1)‚Äãx1+Œª1‚Äãzandx~2‚âî(1‚àíŒª1)‚Äãx2+Œª1‚Äãzformulae-sequence‚âîsubscript~ùë•11subscriptùúÜ1subscriptùë•1subscriptùúÜ1ùëßand‚âîsubscript~ùë•21subscriptùúÜ1subscriptùë•2subscriptùúÜ1ùëß\tilde{x}_{1}\coloneqq(1-\lambda_{1})x_{1}+\lambda_{1}z\quad\text{and}\quad\tilde{x}_{2}\coloneqq(1-\lambda_{1})x_{2}+\lambda_{1}z

satisfy

‚à•x~1‚à•=1and‚à•x~2‚à•‚â•1.formulae-sequencedelimited-‚à•‚à•subscript~ùë•11anddelimited-‚à•‚à•subscript~ùë•21\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\tilde{x}_{1}\right\rVert}=1\quad\text{and}\quad\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\tilde{x}_{2}\right\rVert}\geq 1.

Definition of retraction yields r‚Äã(x~1)=r‚Äã(x1)ùëüsubscript~ùë•1ùëüsubscriptùë•1r(\tilde{x}_{1})=r(x_{1}) and r‚Äã(x~2)=r‚Äã(x2)ùëüsubscript~ùë•2ùëüsubscriptùë•2r(\tilde{x}_{2})=r(x_{2}). Thus, applying (11.3) for x~1subscript~ùë•1\tilde{x}_{1} and x~2subscript~ùë•2\tilde{x}_{2}, we get

‚à•r‚Äã(x1)‚àír‚Äã(x2)‚à•=‚à•r‚Äã(x~1)‚àír‚Äã(x~2)‚à•‚â§(2/Œ≤)‚Äã‚à•x~1‚àíx~2‚à•=(2/Œ≤)‚Äã(1‚àíŒª1)‚Äã‚à•x1‚àíx2‚à•‚â§(2/Œ≤)‚Äã‚à•x1‚àíx2‚à•.delimited-‚à•‚à•ùëüsubscriptùë•1ùëüsubscriptùë•2delimited-‚à•‚à•ùëüsubscript~ùë•1ùëüsubscript~ùë•22ùõΩdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscript~ùë•1subscript~ùë•22ùõΩ1subscriptùúÜ1delimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë•1subscriptùë•22ùõΩdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùë•1subscriptùë•2\begin{split}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert r(x_{1})-r(x_{2})\right\rVert}=\mathinner{\!\left\lVert r(\tilde{x}_{1})-r(\tilde{x}_{2})\right\rVert}\leq(2/\beta)\mathinner{\!\left\lVert\tilde{x}_{1}-\tilde{x}_{2}\right\rVert}\\ =(2/\beta)(1-\lambda_{1})\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x_{1}-x_{2}\right\rVert}\leq(2/\beta)\mathinner{\!\left\lVert x_{1}-x_{2}\right\rVert}.\end{split}

The lemma is proved. ‚àé

Now we extend our analysis of shrinkage for affine subspaces:

Lemma 11.2 (Shrinkage for subspaces).

Let KùêæK be the unit ball of a finite dimensional normed space XùëãX. H~=(1‚àíŒª)‚ÄãH+Œª‚Äãz~ùêª1ùúÜùêªùúÜùëß\tilde{H}=(1-\lambda)H+\lambda z

dX‚Äã(H~1,H~2)‚â§2Œ≤‚ÄãdX‚Äã(H1,H2).subscriptùëëùëãsubscript~ùêª1subscript~ùêª22ùõΩsubscriptùëëùëãsubscriptùêª1subscriptùêª2d_{X}(\tilde{H}_{1},\tilde{H}_{2})\leq\frac{2}{\beta}\,d_{X}(H_{1},H_{2}).

Finally, we specialize our analysis to the shrinkage onto the cube:

Lemma 11.3 (Shrinkage onto a cube).

Let 0<a<c<(a+b)/20ùëéùëêùëéùëè20<a<c<(a+b)/2. where Œª=Œª‚Äã(H)ùúÜùúÜùêª\lambda=\lambda(H) is the minimal number in [0,1]01[0,1] such that H~‚à©[a,b]m‚â†‚àÖ~ùêªsuperscriptùëéùëèùëö\tilde{H}\cap[a,b]^{m}\neq\emptyset. d‚àû‚Äã(H~1,H~2)‚â§b‚àíac‚àía‚Äãd‚àû‚Äã(H1,H2).subscriptùëësubscript~ùêª1subscript~ùêª2ùëèùëéùëêùëésubscriptùëësubscriptùêª1subscriptùêª2d_{\infty}(\tilde{H}_{1},\tilde{H}_{2})\leq\frac{b-a}{c-a}\,d_{\infty}(H_{1},H_{2}).

and

0‚â§a+b2‚àíc=(1‚àíŒ≤)‚Äãb‚àía2for¬†‚ÄãŒ≤=2‚Äã(c‚àía)b‚àía,formulae-sequence0ùëéùëè2ùëê1ùõΩùëèùëé2for¬†ùõΩ2ùëêùëéùëèùëé0\leq\frac{a+b}{2}-c=(1-\beta)\frac{b-a}{2}\quad\text{for }\beta=\frac{2(c-a)}{b-a},
