Therefore, the conclusion holds for the L‚àûsuperscriptùêøL^{\infty} norm as well. ‚àé

12. Privacy and accuracy of the algorithm

We are ready to analyze the privacy and accuracy of Algorithm¬†1.

12.1. Algorithm

For convenience we rewrite Algorithm¬†1, see Algorithm¬†2 below. Also note that in Step 5 of Algorithm¬†2, the L2‚Äã(S)superscriptùêø2ùëÜL^{2}(S)-norm is defined as ‚à•h‚à•L2‚Äã(S)2=1m‚Äã‚àëi=1mh‚Äã(si)2superscriptsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚Ñésuperscriptùêø2ùëÜ21ùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëö‚Ñésuperscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñ2\mathinner{\!\left\lVert h\right\rVert}_{L^{2}(S)}^{2}=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}h(s_{i})^{2}.

The standing assumption in this section is that the reduced space S=(s1,‚Ä¶,sm)ùëÜsubscriptùë†1‚Ä¶subscriptùë†ùëöS=(s_{1},\ldots,s_{m}) is random, and consists of points sisubscriptùë†ùëñs_{i} drawn independently and uniformly from the cube. We would like to show that with high probability over SùëÜS, the algorithm is differentially private.

12.2. Sensitivity of density

The privacy guarantee will be achieved via Private Sampling Lemma¬†3.3. To apply it, we need to bound the sensitivity of the density h‚àósuperscript‚Ñéh^{*} computed by the algorithm.

Lemma 12.1.

Suppose the reduced space SùëÜS is well conditioned. Then, for any pair of input datasets X1subscriptùëã1X_{1} and X2subscriptùëã2X_{2} that consist of at least nùëõn elements each and differ from each other by a single element, the densities h1‚àósubscriptsuperscript‚Ñé1h^{*}_{1} and h2‚àósubscriptsuperscript‚Ñé2h^{*}_{2} computed by the algorithm satisfy

‚à•h1‚àó‚àíh2‚àó‚à•‚àû‚â§4‚Äã2‚ÄãŒî3/2‚Äãed/2Œ¥‚Äãn‚Äãm1/4‚Äã(p‚â§d)1/4.subscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptsuperscript‚Ñé1subscriptsuperscript‚Ñé242superscriptŒî32superscriptùëíùëë2ùõøùëõsuperscriptùëö14superscriptbinomialùëùabsentùëë14\mathinner{\!\left\lVert h^{*}_{1}-h^{*}_{2}\right\rVert}_{\infty}\leq\frac{4\sqrt{2}\Delta^{3/2}e^{d/2}}{\sqrt{\delta n}\,m^{1/4}}\binom{p}{\leq d}^{1/4}.
Proof.

By Proposition¬†9.4, the solution subspaces

H1=H‚Äã(fn)andH2=H‚Äã(fn+1)formulae-sequencesubscriptùêª1ùêªsubscriptùëìùëõandsubscriptùêª2ùêªsubscriptùëìùëõ1H_{1}=H(f_{n})\quad\text{and}\quad H_{2}=H(f_{n+1})

are translates of each other. The ambient space consists of all functions supported on an mùëöm-element set SùëÜS, and thus can be identified with ‚Ñùmsuperscript‚Ñùùëö\mathbb{R}^{m}. Let H~isubscript~ùêªùëñ\tilde{H}_{i} be the result of shrinkage of the subspaces HisubscriptùêªùëñH_{i} toward the uniform distribution as specified in the algorithm, i.e. the shrinkage onto the cube [Œ¥/m,Œî/m]msuperscriptùõøùëöŒîùëöùëö[\delta/m,\Delta/m]^{m} and toward the uniform distribution umsubscriptùë¢ùëöu_{m}. The selection rule for h‚àósuperscript‚Ñéh^{*} specified in the algorithm is stable in the L‚àûsuperscriptùêøL^{\infty} metric. Indeed, Lemma¬†10.4 applied for the subspaces H~isubscript~ùêªùëñ\tilde{H}_{i} and for

a=2‚ÄãŒ¥m,b=Œî‚àíŒ¥m,c=1m,Œª=Œ¥mformulae-sequenceùëé2ùõøùëöformulae-sequenceùëèŒîùõøùëöformulae-sequenceùëê1ùëöùúÜùõøùëöa=\frac{2\delta}{m},\quad b=\frac{\Delta-\delta}{m},\quad c=\frac{1}{m},\quad\lambda=\frac{\delta}{m}

yields

‚à•h1‚àó‚àíh2‚àó‚à•‚àû2‚â§4‚ÄãŒî2Œ¥‚ãÖd‚àû‚Äã(H~1,H~2).superscriptsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptsuperscript‚Ñé1subscriptsuperscript‚Ñé22‚ãÖ4superscriptŒî2ùõøsubscriptùëësubscript~ùêª1subscript~ùêª2\mathinner{\!\left\lVert h^{*}_{1}-h^{*}_{2}\right\rVert}_{\infty}^{2}\leq\frac{4\Delta^{2}}{\delta}\cdot d_{\infty}(\tilde{H}_{1},\tilde{H}_{2}).

Next, recall that the shrinkage map is stable. Indeed, Lemma¬†11.3 applied for the same a,b,cùëéùëèùëêa,b,c yields

d‚àû‚Äã(H~1,H~2)‚â§2‚ÄãŒî‚ãÖd‚àû‚Äã(H1,H2).subscriptùëësubscript~ùêª1subscript~ùêª2‚ãÖ2Œîsubscriptùëësubscriptùêª1subscriptùêª2d_{\infty}(\tilde{H}_{1},\tilde{H}_{2})\leq 2\Delta\cdot d_{\infty}(H_{1},H_{2}).

Furthermore, the solution space is stable. Indeed, Lemma¬†9.5 for the uniform density Œºùúá\mu on the cube yields

d‚àû‚Äã(H1,H2)‚â§2‚Äãed‚Äã2pm‚Äã‚à•(fn‚àífn+1)‚â§d‚à•L2.subscriptùëësubscriptùêª1subscriptùêª22superscriptùëíùëësuperscript2ùëùùëösubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëìùëõ1absentùëësuperscriptùêø2d_{\infty}(H_{1},H_{2})\leq\frac{2e^{d}2^{p}}{\sqrt{m}}\,\mathinner{\!\bigl{\lVert}(f_{n}-f_{n+1})^{\leq d}\bigr{\rVert}}_{L^{2}}.

Finally, recall from (9.6) that

‚à•(fn+1‚àífn)‚â§d‚à•L2‚â§2n‚Äã(p‚â§d)1/2‚Äã12p.subscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùëìùëõ1subscriptùëìùëõabsentùëësuperscriptùêø22ùëõsuperscriptbinomialùëùabsentùëë121superscript2ùëù\mathinner{\!\bigl{\lVert}(f_{n+1}-f_{n})^{\leq d}\bigr{\rVert}}_{L^{2}}\leq\frac{2}{n}\binom{p}{\leq d}^{1/2}\frac{1}{2^{p}}.

Combining all these bounds, we conclude that

‚à•h1‚àó‚àíh2‚àó‚à•‚àû2‚â§4‚ÄãŒî2Œ¥‚ãÖ2‚ÄãŒî‚ãÖ2‚Äãed‚Äã2pm‚ãÖ2n‚Äã(p‚â§d)1/2‚Äã12p‚â§32‚ÄãŒî3‚ÄãedŒ¥‚Äãn‚Äãm‚Äã(p‚â§d)1/2.superscriptsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptsuperscript‚Ñé1subscriptsuperscript‚Ñé22‚ãÖ‚ãÖ4superscriptŒî2ùõø2Œî2superscriptùëíùëësuperscript2ùëùùëö2ùëõsuperscriptbinomialùëùabsentùëë121superscript2ùëù32superscriptŒî3superscriptùëíùëëùõøùëõùëösuperscriptbinomialùëùabsentùëë12\mathinner{\!\left\lVert h^{*}_{1}-h^{*}_{2}\right\rVert}_{\infty}^{2}\leq\frac{4\Delta^{2}}{\delta}\cdot 2\Delta\cdot\frac{2e^{d}2^{p}}{\sqrt{m}}\cdot\frac{2}{n}\binom{p}{\leq d}^{1/2}\frac{1}{2^{p}}\leq\frac{32\Delta^{3}e^{d}}{\delta n\sqrt{m}}\binom{p}{\leq d}^{1/2}.

The proof is complete. ‚àé

12.3. Privacy guarantee

Finally, we are ready to give the privacy guarantee of our algorithm:

Theorem 12.2 (Privacy).

If k‚â§14‚Äã2‚ÄãŒµ‚Äã(Œ¥/Œî)3/2‚Äãe‚àíd/2‚Äã(p‚â§d)‚àí1/4‚Äãn/m3/4ùëò142ùúÄsuperscriptùõøŒî32superscriptùëíùëë2superscriptbinomialùëùabsentùëë14ùëõsuperscriptùëö34k\leq\frac{1}{4\sqrt{2}}\varepsilon(\delta/\Delta)^{3/2}e^{-d/2}\binom{p}{\leq d}^{-1/4}\sqrt{n}/m^{3/4}, then Algorithm¬†2 is ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon-differentially private.

Proof.

Since the reduced space SùëÜS is drawn independently of the input data XùëãX, we can condition on SùëÜS. If SùëÜS is ill conditioned, the algorithm returns ‚ÄúFailure‚Äù regardless of the input data, so the privacy holds trivially. Suppose SùëÜS is well conditioned.

Let X1subscriptùëã1X_{1} and X2subscriptùëã2X_{2} be a pair of datasets that consist of at least nùëõn elements each and differ from each other by a single element. By the choice made in the algorithm and by sensitivity of density (Lemma¬†12.1), we have

h2‚àó‚â•Œ¥mand|h1‚àó‚àíh2‚àó|‚â§4‚Äã2‚ÄãŒî3/2‚Äãed/2Œ¥‚Äãn‚Äãm1/4‚Äã(p‚â§d)1/4‚âïŒ∑formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript‚Ñé2ùõøùëöandsubscriptsuperscript‚Ñé1subscriptsuperscript‚Ñé242superscriptŒî32superscriptùëíùëë2ùõøùëõsuperscriptùëö14superscriptbinomialùëùabsentùëë14‚âïùúÇh^{*}_{2}\geq\frac{\delta}{m}\quad\text{and}\quad\mathinner{\!\left\lvert h^{*}_{1}-h^{*}_{2}\right\rvert}\leq\frac{4\sqrt{2}\Delta^{3/2}e^{d/2}}{\sqrt{\delta n}\,m^{1/4}}\binom{p}{\leq d}^{1/4}\eqqcolon\eta

pointwise. Therefore

|h1‚àó/h2‚àó|‚â§1+Œ∑‚ÄãmŒ¥‚â§exp‚Å°(Œ∑‚ÄãmŒ¥)‚â§exp‚Å°(Œµk)subscriptsuperscript‚Ñé1subscriptsuperscript‚Ñé21ùúÇùëöùõøùúÇùëöùõøùúÄùëò\mathinner{\!\left\lvert h^{*}_{1}/h^{*}_{2}\right\rvert}\leq 1+\frac{\eta m}{\delta}\leq\exp\Big{(}\frac{\eta m}{\delta}\Big{)}\leq\exp\Big{(}\frac{\varepsilon}{k}\Big{)}

pointwise, where the last inequality indeed holds due to our assumption on kùëòk. Private Sampling Lemma¬†3.3 completes the proof. ‚àé

Remark 12.3.

Suppose we chose the size mùëöm of the reduced space SùëÜS so that m‚âçe2‚Äãd‚Äã(p‚â§d)asymptotically-equalsùëösuperscriptùëí2ùëëbinomialùëùabsentùëëm\asymp e^{2d}\binom{p}{\leq d}. Simplifying the condition in Theorem¬†12.2, we conclude that if k‚â™n/mmuch-less-thanùëòùëõùëök\ll\sqrt{n}/m, then Algorithm¬†2 is o‚Äã(1)ùëú1o(1)-differentially private.

12.4. Accuracy guarantee

The following is the accuracy guarantee of our algorithm:

Theorem 12.4 (Accuracy).

Assume the true data X=(x1,‚Ä¶,xn)ùëãsubscriptùë•1‚Ä¶subscriptùë•ùëõX=(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}) is drawn independently from the cube according to some density fùëìf, which satisfies ‚à•f‚à•‚àû‚â§Œî/2psubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëìŒîsuperscript2ùëù\mathinner{\!\left\lVert f\right\rVert}_{\infty}\leq\Delta/2^{p}. Assume that n‚â•16‚ÄãŒ¥‚àí2‚ÄãŒ≥‚àí1‚Äãe2‚Äãd‚Äã(p‚â§d)ùëõ16superscriptùõø2superscriptùõæ1superscriptùëí2ùëëbinomialùëùabsentùëën\geq 16\delta^{-2}\gamma^{-1}e^{2d}\binom{p}{\leq d}, 16‚ÄãŒ¥‚àí2‚ÄãŒ≥‚àí1‚ÄãŒî2‚Äãe2‚Äãd‚Äã(p‚â§d)‚â§m‚â§2p/416superscriptùõø2superscriptùõæ1superscriptŒî2superscriptùëí2ùëëbinomialùëùabsentùëëùëösuperscript2ùëù416\delta^{-2}\gamma^{-1}\Delta^{2}e^{2d}\binom{p}{\leq d}\leq m\leq 2^{p/4}, and k‚â•4‚ÄãŒ¥‚àí2‚Äã(log‚Å°(2/Œ≥)+log‚Å°(p‚â§d))ùëò4superscriptùõø22ùõæbinomialùëùabsentùëëk\geq 4\delta^{-2}(\log(2/\gamma)+\log\binom{p}{\leq d}). Then, with probability at least 1‚àí4‚ÄãŒ≥‚àí12p14ùõæ1superscript2ùëù1-4\gamma-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2^{p}}}, the algorithm succeeds, and all marginals of the synthetic data YùëåY up to dimension dùëëd are within 4‚ÄãŒ¥4ùõø4\delta from the corresponding marginals of the true data XùëãX.

Proof.

Proposition¬†9.3 and the choice of mùëöm guarantee that the algorithm succeeds with probability at least 1‚àíŒ≥1ùõæ1-\gamma.

Furthermore, the uniform density on the cube g=2‚àípùëîsuperscript2ùëùg=2^{-p} satisfies ‚à•f/g‚à•L2‚â§‚à•f/g‚à•‚àû=‚à•f‚à•‚àû‚ãÖ2p‚â§Œîsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëìùëîsuperscriptùêø2subscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëìùëî‚ãÖsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëìsuperscript2ùëùŒî\mathinner{\!\left\lVert f/g\right\rVert}_{L^{2}}\leq\mathinner{\!\left\lVert f/g\right\rVert}_{\infty}=\mathinner{\!\left\lVert f\right\rVert}_{\infty}\cdot 2^{p}\leq\Delta. Therefore, Theorem¬†8.1 implies that with probability at least 1‚àí2‚ÄãŒ≥12ùõæ1-2\gamma, there exists h‚ààH=H‚Äã(fn)‚Ñéùêªùêªsubscriptùëìùëõh\in H=H(f_{n}) such that

‚à•h‚àí(f/g)‚Äãgm‚à•‚àû‚â§Œ¥m.subscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚Ñéùëìùëîsubscriptùëîùëöùõøùëö\mathinner{\!\left\lVert h-(f/g)g_{m}\right\rVert}_{\infty}\leq\frac{\delta}{m}. (12.1)

Since (f/g)‚Äãgmùëìùëîsubscriptùëîùëö(f/g)g_{m} is a nonnegative function, it follows that

h‚â•‚àíŒ¥mpointwise.‚Ñéùõøùëöpointwiseh\geq-\frac{\delta}{m}\quad\text{pointwise}.

The assumption m‚â§2p/4ùëösuperscript2ùëù4m\leq 2^{p/4} implies that with probability 1‚àí12p11superscript2ùëù1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2^{p}}} there are no repetitions in y1,‚Ä¶,ymsubscriptùë¶1‚Ä¶subscriptùë¶ùëöy_{1},\ldots,y_{m}, which in turn implies that with probability 1‚àí12p11superscript2ùëù1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2^{p}}} we have ‚à•gm‚à•‚àû‚â§1/msubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùëîùëö1ùëö\mathinner{\!\left\lVert g_{m}\right\rVert}_{\infty}\leq 1/m (otherwise ‚à•gm‚à•‚àûsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùëîùëö\mathinner{\!\left\lVert g_{m}\right\rVert}_{\infty} would scale with the number of repetitions in y1,‚Ä¶,ymsubscriptùë¶1‚Ä¶subscriptùë¶ùëöy_{1},\ldots,y_{m}).

In the following we condition on the event that there are no repetitions in y1,‚Ä¶,ymsubscriptùë¶1‚Ä¶subscriptùë¶ùëöy_{1},\ldots,y_{m}. Since ‚à•f/g‚à•‚àû‚â§Œîsubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëìùëîŒî\mathinner{\!\left\lVert f/g\right\rVert}_{\infty}\leq\Delta by above and ‚à•gm‚à•‚àû‚â§1/msubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùëîùëö1ùëö\mathinner{\!\left\lVert g_{m}\right\rVert}_{\infty}\leq 1/m, we have ‚à•(f/g)‚Äãgm‚à•‚àû‚â§Œî/msubscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëìùëîsubscriptùëîùëöŒîùëö\mathinner{\!\left\lVert(f/g)g_{m}\right\rVert}_{\infty}\leq\Delta/m, so

h‚â§Œî+Œ¥mpointwise.‚ÑéŒîùõøùëöpointwiseh\leq\frac{\Delta+\delta}{m}\quad\text{pointwise}.

A combination of these two bounds on h‚Ñéh implies that

2‚ÄãŒ¥m‚â§(1‚àí3‚ÄãŒ¥)‚Äãh+3‚ÄãŒ¥m‚â§Œî‚àíŒ¥mpointwise,formulae-sequence2ùõøùëö13ùõø‚Ñé3ùõøùëöŒîùõøùëöpointwise\frac{2\delta}{m}\leq(1-3\delta)h+\frac{3\delta}{m}\leq\frac{\Delta-\delta}{m}\quad\text{pointwise},

as long as Œî‚â•5/3Œî53\Delta\geq 5/3. Since h‚ààH‚Ñéùêªh\in H, it follows that the affine subspace (1‚àí3‚ÄãŒ¥)‚ÄãH+3‚ÄãŒ¥‚Äãum13ùõøùêª3ùõøsubscriptùë¢ùëö(1-3\delta)H+3\delta u_{m} has a nonempty intersection with [2‚ÄãŒ¥/m,(Œî‚àíŒ¥)/m]msuperscript2ùõøùëöŒîùõøùëöùëö[2\delta/m,(\Delta-\delta)/m]^{m}. The minimality property of ŒªùúÜ\lambda in the algorithm yields

Œª‚â§3‚ÄãŒ¥.ùúÜ3ùõø\lambda\leq 3\delta. (12.2)

Recall that a marginal of a function f:{‚àí1,1}p‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëìsuperscript11ùëù‚Üí‚Ñùf\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}\{-1,1\}^{p}\to\mathbb{R} that corresponds to a subset J‚äÇ[p]ùêΩdelimited-[]ùëùJ\subset[p] of parameters and values Œ∏j‚àà{‚àí1,1}subscriptùúÉùëó11\theta_{j}\in\{-1,1\} for j‚ààJùëóùêΩj\in J, is defined as

P‚Äã(f)=‚àëx‚àà{‚àí1,1}pf‚Äã(x)‚Äãv‚Äã(x)ùëÉùëìsubscriptùë•superscript11ùëùùëìùë•ùë£ùë•P(f)=\sum_{x\in\{-1,1\}^{p}}f(x)v(x)

where v‚Äã(x)=1{x‚Äã(j)=Œ∏j‚Äã‚àÄj‚ààJ}ùë£ùë•subscript1ùë•ùëósubscriptùúÉùëófor-allùëóùêΩv(x)={\textbf{1}}_{\{x(j)=\theta_{j}\;\forall j\in J\}}.

Recall that the solution h‚àósuperscript‚Ñéh^{*} of the algorithm satisfies

h‚àó‚ààH~=(1‚àíŒª)‚ÄãH+Œª‚Äãumsuperscript‚Ñé~ùêª1ùúÜùêªùúÜsubscriptùë¢ùëöh^{*}\in\tilde{H}=(1-\lambda)H+\lambda u_{m}

and, by definition of HùêªH, all members of HùêªH have the same marginals up to dimension dùëëd as fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n}. This and linearity implies that for any marginal up to dimension dùëëd,

P‚Äã(h‚àó)=(1‚àíŒª)‚ÄãP‚Äã(fn)+Œª‚ÄãP‚Äã(um)ùëÉsuperscript‚Ñé1ùúÜùëÉsubscriptùëìùëõùúÜùëÉsubscriptùë¢ùëöP(h^{*})=(1-\lambda)P(f_{n})+\lambda P(u_{m})

Hence

|P‚Äã(h‚àó)‚àíP‚Äã(fn)|‚â§Œª‚Äã|P‚Äã(um)‚àíP‚Äã(fn)|ùëÉsuperscript‚ÑéùëÉsubscriptùëìùëõùúÜùëÉsubscriptùë¢ùëöùëÉsubscriptùëìùëõ\mathinner{\!\left\lvert P(h^{*})-P(f_{n})\right\rvert}\leq\lambda\mathinner{\!\left\lvert P(u_{m})-P(f_{n})\right\rvert}

Since umsubscriptùë¢ùëöu_{m} and fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n} are densities, all of their marginals must be within [0,1]01[0,1], so |P‚Äã(um)‚àíP‚Äã(fn)|‚â§1ùëÉsubscriptùë¢ùëöùëÉsubscriptùëìùëõ1\mathinner{\!\left\lvert P(u_{m})-P(f_{n})\right\rvert}\leq 1. Combining this with (12.2), we get

|P‚Äã(h‚àó)‚àíP‚Äã(fn)|‚â§3‚ÄãŒ¥,ùëÉsuperscript‚ÑéùëÉsubscriptùëìùëõ3ùõø\mathinner{\!\left\lvert P(h^{*})-P(f_{n})\right\rvert}\leq 3\delta, (12.3)

for all marginals up to dimension dùëëd, with probability at least 1‚àí2‚ÄãŒ≥12ùõæ1-2\gamma.

Now we compare the marginals of the density h‚àósuperscript‚Ñéh^{*} and its empirical counterpart hk‚àósubscriptsuperscript‚Ñéùëòh^{*}_{k}. We can express

P‚Äã(hk‚àó)‚àíP‚Äã(h‚àó)=1k‚Äã‚àëi=1k(v‚Äã(Yi)‚àíùîº‚Å°v‚Äã(Yi))ùëÉsubscriptsuperscript‚ÑéùëòùëÉsuperscript‚Ñé1ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëòùë£subscriptùëåùëñùîºùë£subscriptùëåùëñP(h^{*}_{k})-P(h^{*})=\frac{1}{k}\sum_{i=1}^{k}\left(v(Y_{i})-\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}v(Y_{i})\right)

where YisubscriptùëåùëñY_{i} are i.i.d. random variables drawn according to the density h‚àósuperscript‚Ñéh^{*}. Thus, we have a normalized and centered sum of i.i.d. Bernoulli random variables, so Bernstein‚Äôs inequality (see e.g. [41, Theorem¬†2.8.4]) yields

‚Ñô‚Äã{|P‚Äã(hk‚àó)‚àíP‚Äã(h‚àó)|>Œ¥‚Äã}‚â§2‚Äãexp‚Å°(‚àíŒ¥2‚Äãk/4)‚â§Œ≥‚Äã(p‚â§d)‚àí1‚ÑôùëÉsubscriptsuperscript‚ÑéùëòùëÉsuperscript‚Ñéùõø2superscriptùõø2ùëò4ùõæsuperscriptbinomialùëùabsentùëë1\mathbb{P}\left\{\mathinner{\!\left\lvert P(h^{*}_{k})-P(h^{*})\right\rvert}>\delta\rule{0.0pt}{8.53581pt}\right\}\leq 2\exp(-\delta^{2}k/4)\leq\gamma\binom{p}{\leq d}^{-1}

if k‚â•4‚ÄãŒ¥‚àí2‚Äã(log‚Å°(2/Œ≥)+log‚Å°(p‚â§d))ùëò4superscriptùõø22ùõæbinomialùëùabsentùëëk\geq 4\delta^{-2}(\log(2/\gamma)+\log\binom{p}{\leq d}). Thus, by a union bound, we have

|P‚Äã(hk‚àó)‚àíP‚Äã(h‚àó)|‚â§Œ¥,ùëÉsubscriptsuperscript‚ÑéùëòùëÉsuperscript‚Ñéùõø\mathinner{\!\left\lvert P(h^{*}_{k})-P(h^{*})\right\rvert}\leq\delta,

simultaneously for all marginals up to dimension dùëëd, with probability at least 1‚àíŒ≥1ùõæ1-\gamma.

Combining this with (12.3) via the triangle inequality, we conclude that

|P‚Äã(hk‚àó)‚àíP‚Äã(fn)|‚â§4‚ÄãŒ¥,ùëÉsubscriptsuperscript‚ÑéùëòùëÉsubscriptùëìùëõ4ùõø\mathinner{\!\left\lvert P(h^{*}_{k})-P(f_{n})\right\rvert}\leq 4\delta,

for all marginals up to dimension dùëëd, with probability at least 1‚àí3‚ÄãŒ≥13ùõæ1-3\gamma. Recalling that we conditioned on an event with probability 1‚àí1/p11ùëù1-1/\sqrt{p} and applying the union bound completes the proof. ‚àé

Remark 12.5 (No shrinkage for regular densities).

If the density fùëìf from which the true data XùëãX is drawn is regular, specifically if 3‚ÄãŒ¥/2p‚â§f‚â§(Œî‚àí2‚ÄãŒ¥)/2p3ùõøsuperscript2ùëùùëìŒî2ùõøsuperscript2ùëù3\delta/2^{p}\leq f\leq(\Delta-2\delta)/2^{p} pointwise for some positive numbers Œ¥ùõø\delta and ŒîŒî\Delta, the algorithm does not apply any shrinkage. Indeed, in this case we have 3‚ÄãŒ¥/m‚â§(f/g)‚Äãgm‚â§(Œî‚àí2‚ÄãŒ¥)‚Äãm3ùõøùëöùëìùëîsubscriptùëîùëöŒî2ùõøùëö3\delta/m\leq(f/g)g_{m}\leq(\Delta-2\delta)m, so it follows from (12.1) that 2‚ÄãŒ¥/m‚â§h‚â§(Œî‚àíŒ¥)‚Äãm2ùõøùëö‚ÑéŒîùõøùëö2\delta/m\leq h\leq(\Delta-\delta)m, and thus HùêªH has a nonempty intersection with [2‚ÄãŒ¥/m,(Œî‚àíŒ¥)‚Äãm]Ssuperscript2ùõøùëöŒîùõøùëöùëÜ[2\delta/m,(\Delta-\delta)m]^{S}, hence Œª=0ùúÜ0\lambda=0.
